summary_llm:
This detailed summary is based solely on the provided text of "A Doll's House."

**Act I**

The play opens in the comfortably furnished home of Nora and Torvald Helmer during winter. Nora enters in high spirits, carrying Christmas parcels, and instructs the maid to hide the Christmas tree from the children. She secretly eats macaroons, which her husband, Torvald, has forbidden. Torvald, a lawyer who is soon to become manager of the Bank, enters, playfully calling Nora his "little lark" and "little squirrel," and chides her for being a "spendthrift." Nora argues that they can afford to spend more now that Torvald has a secure, high-paying position, but Torvald insists on no debt or borrowing, believing it destroys freedom and beauty in a home. He gives her money for Christmas, and Nora shows him the inexpensive gifts she bought for their three children (Ivar, Bob, and Emmy) and the maids, but keeps one parcel secret. When asked what she wants, Nora suggests money, which she claims she will save to buy something for herself, though Torvald doubts her ability to save. He also observes her looking uneasy and teases her about eating sweets, which she denies.

Nora asks if Doctor Rank has been invited for Christmas dinner, and Torvald confirms he will come. They discuss their plans for Christmas and Nora's past efforts to make Christmas ornaments, which were ruined by a cat. A bell rings, and the maid announces a lady caller and Doctor Rank. Torvald goes into his study with Dr. Rank.

The visitor is Mrs. Linde, an old school friend whom Nora initially doesn't recognize due to her changed appearance. Mrs. Linde reveals she is a widow of three years, with no children, and her husband left her nothing. She explains she married him to provide for her bedridden mother and two younger brothers, but now her mother has died and her brothers are self-sufficient, leaving her feeling "unspeakably empty" and in need of work. Nora expresses delight at Torvald's new bank position, which will bring them financial security, and promises to speak to Torvald about getting Mrs. Linde a job.

Nora then reveals a secret to Mrs. Linde: she was the one who procured the money for Torvald's life-saving trip to Italy eight years ago, not her father, as Torvald believes. She explains that Torvald had overworked himself and become dreadfully ill, and doctors said he needed to go south. Knowing Torvald's strong opinions against borrowing and his "manly independence," Nora secretly borrowed two hundred and fifty pounds. She tried to persuade Torvald to travel by pretending she wanted to travel like other young wives, using tears and entreaties, and even hinting at a loan, but he refused. Her father died around the same time, preventing Nora from asking him to sign the bond or revealing her secret to him. Nora has been secretly repaying the loan through "odds and ends, needlework, crotchet-work, embroidery," and copying work, often buying the cheapest clothes for herself to save money, and always ensuring Torvald had a good table and the children were well-dressed. She describes the difficulty of managing quarterly interest and installments. She is now "free from care" as the debt is almost paid off.

Krogstad, a lawyer, arrives and asks to speak with Helmer about bank business. Mrs. Linde recognizes him and trembles, revealing she knew him many years ago when he was a solicitor's clerk. Dr. Rank emerges from Helmer's study and mentions Krogstad is a "morally diseased" man who is currently with Helmer. Nora, amused by the idea of Torvald having power over so many people, offers Dr. Rank a macaroon, which Torvald has forbidden her to eat. Dr. Rank confesses he thought macaroons were forbidden. Nora then playfully admits she would love to say "Well, I'm damned!" if Torvald could hear her.

Helmer joins them, and Nora introduces Mrs. Linde, exaggerating that Mrs. Linde traveled to see Helmer and is "tremendously clever at book-keeping" and "frightfully anxious to work." Helmer, learning Mrs. Linde is a widow with experience, says he may be able to find her a position. Helmer, Dr. Rank, and Mrs. Linde leave for a walk. Nora plays with her children, but Krogstad returns, finding the outer door ajar.

Krogstad confronts Nora, stating he knows about her influence and that Mrs. Linde is taking his position at the bank. He demands Nora use her influence to ensure he keeps his "subordinate position." Nora denies having such influence, but Krogstad threatens to expose her secret loan and forgery. He reminds her that when she borrowed the money, she signed a bond, and her father was supposed to sign as surety. Krogstad reveals that her father's signature on the bond is dated three days *after* his death, and the date itself is not in her father's handwriting. Nora confesses she forged her father's signature because he was dying, and she couldn't tell him Torvald's life was in danger. Krogstad warns her that the law cares nothing for motives and that her action constitutes fraud. He declares that if he loses his position, she will lose hers with him. Nora dismisses his threats, believing she did it "for love's sake."

Helmer returns and immediately senses Krogstad has been there begging Nora to intercede for him. He scolds Nora for speaking with Krogstad and lying to him. Helmer reveals he has the authority to make changes at the bank and plans to dismiss Krogstad. He explains that Krogstad "forged someone's name" and that such a "guilty man" poisons his home with lies, infecting his children. Helmer makes Nora promise not to plead Krogstad's cause, stating he feels "physically ill" in Krogstad's company and cannot work with him due to his past "indiscretion" and overly familiar behavior. Nora is left terrified, whispering, "No, no—it isn’t true. It’s impossible; it must be impossible." She refuses to let her children come in, fearing she might "deprave" or "poison" them.

**Act II**

Nora is anxious and uneasy, looking for letters in the letterbox. She speaks to the Nurse, asking if her children would forget her if she "went away altogether," and inquires about the Nurse's own experience of leaving her child to work for Nora's family. Mrs. Linde arrives to help Nora mend her Neapolitan fisher-girl costume for the fancy-dress ball.

Nora confides in Mrs. Linde about Dr. Rank's dangerous illness, consumption of the spine, which she attributes to his father's excesses. Mrs. Linde, noticing Dr. Rank's frequent visits, questions his sincerity and suggests Nora should "make an end of it" with him. She then guesses that Dr. Rank lent Nora the money, but Nora vehemently denies it, stating he had no money then. Nora confirms she needs to "make an end of it with the other one" (Krogstad).

Helmer returns, and Nora attempts once more to persuade him to keep Krogstad, arguing that Krogstad writes for "scurrilous newspapers" and can do Helmer "unspeakable amount of harm." Helmer dismisses her fears, attributing them to her thinking of her father's past reputation. He reiterates that he cannot keep Krogstad due to his moral failings and, more importantly, because Krogstad's familiar tone ("I say, Helmer, old fellow!") would make Helmer appear weak and swayed by outside influence to his staff. Helmer calls Nora "narrow-minded" for questioning his reasoning and sends the maid with Krogstad's dismissal letter.

Nora is distraught, begging Helmer to recall the letter for their sake and the children's. Helmer says it's too late and embraces her, assuring her he will have "courage and strength" and is "man enough to take everything upon myself" if anything comes of it. He then tells her to practice her Tarantella dance.

Dr. Rank arrives, and Nora tries to prevent him from seeing Torvald, but he insists. Dr. Rank reveals he is terminally ill with "consumption of the spine" and will soon be "rotting in the churchyard." He explains his illness is a "penalty for another man's sin" (his father's excesses). He tells Nora he will send her a card with a black cross when his "loathsome end" has begun, and he will bar Helmer from his sick-room because Helmer has a "disgust at everything that is ugly." Dr. Rank then confesses his love for Nora, saying he would "gladly give his life for your sake." Nora is shocked and distressed by his confession, which prevents her from asking him for the "tremendously big favour" she had intended to ask.

The maid brings Nora a card, which Nora hides, telling Dr. Rank it's about a new dress. She sends Dr. Rank to keep Helmer occupied. Krogstad enters through the back stairs, having received his dismissal. He tells Nora he will not accuse her but demands to be reinstated at the bank in a higher position, becoming Helmer's "right hand." He states he has a letter in his pocket for Helmer, telling him everything "in as lenient a manner as I possibly could." Nora desperately tries to get him to tear up the letter, offering to find money, but Krogstad refuses to part with the bond. He warns her against doing anything foolish, like running away or something worse, as he would still have Helmer "completely in my power." As Krogstad leaves, he drops the letter into the letterbox.

Nora shows Mrs. Linde the letter in the letterbox and confesses she "forged a name." She asks Mrs. Linde to be her witness if she goes out of her mind or disappears, stating she alone did the whole thing. Mrs. Linde believes the secret must be disclosed to Helmer for their own good. Mrs. Linde offers to go and speak to Krogstad, revealing there was a time when he "would gladly do anything for my sake." Nora distracts Helmer from checking the letterbox by insisting he help her practice the Tarantella, claiming she has forgotten it and is "dreadfully afraid." Helmer agrees, promising to dedicate the evening to her and not open any letters. Nora dances wildly, as if her life depends on it, while Helmer and Dr. Rank watch. Mrs. Linde returns, and Nora calls for champagne and macaroons. Helmer and Dr. Rank go to dinner. Mrs. Linde informs Nora that Krogstad has gone out of town but is "coming home tomorrow evening." Nora says she is waiting for "a wonderful thing to happen."

**Act III**

Mrs. Linde is waiting alone in the Helmers' living room, listening for Krogstad. He arrives, and they discuss their past. Mrs. Linde explains she broke their engagement years ago because she had to provide for her sick mother and younger brothers, and Krogstad's prospects seemed hopeless. Krogstad admits he felt "shipwrecked" after losing her. Mrs. Linde proposes they join forces, as she feels her life is "unspeakably empty" without someone to care for. She knows about his past and his reputation but has faith in his "real character" and wants to be a mother to his children. Krogstad is overjoyed.

Krogstad mentions the letter he sent to Helmer, and Mrs. Linde, believing that "this unhappy secret must be disclosed" for Helmer and Nora to have a "complete understanding," tells him not to recall it. Krogstad agrees, saying he will wait for her below. Mrs. Linde tidies the room, reflecting on the difference having someone to work and live for makes.

Helmer and Nora return from the ball. Helmer is in high spirits, praising Nora's Tarantella and her beauty, but also calling her "terribly self-willed." He describes how he brought her home early to preserve the "effect" of her performance. Nora, in a hurried whisper, asks Mrs. Linde what happened with Krogstad. Mrs. Linde confirms she spoke to him and reiterates that Nora "must tell your husband all about it," as the letter will otherwise. Nora responds, "I knew it," and says, "Now I know what I must do."

Mrs. Linde leaves after Helmer makes condescending remarks about her knitting. Helmer then expresses his desire for Nora, describing how he imagines her as his "secretly promised bride." Nora rebuffs his advances, telling him to go away.

Dr. Rank makes an unexpected final visit. He confirms he has received "certainty" about his illness, implying his death is imminent, and that he will be "invisible" at the next fancy-dress ball. He asks Helmer for a cigar, and Nora lights it for him. He says goodbye, and Helmer remarks he has "drunk more than he ought."

Helmer goes to empty the letterbox. He finds two cards from Dr. Rank with black crosses over his name, which Nora confirms is Dr. Rank's way of announcing his impending death. Helmer is saddened but also notes that his death will leave them "thrown quite upon each other now." He expresses a wish that Nora might be threatened by danger so he could risk his life for her. Nora firmly tells him to read his letters. Helmer initially resists, wanting to be with her, but then agrees, saying the thought of death has come between them. He goes into his room to read the letters.

Nora, in a state of terror, whispers about never seeing Helmer or her children again, contemplating the "icy, black water." Helmer rushes out of his room with an open letter, calling her name. He demands to know if she knows what is in the letter. Nora confirms she does and tries to escape, saying, "You shan’t save me, Torvald!" Helmer, reeling, reads the letter and calls Nora a "miserable creature," a "hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a criminal!" He blames her father's "want of principle" for her actions and declares she has "destroyed all my happiness" and "ruined all my future" by putting him in the power of an "unscrupulous man." He fears being falsely suspected of complicity.

Nora, now cold and quiet, acknowledges she understands. Helmer states they must maintain appearances, but he will no longer allow her to bring up the children, as he "dare not trust them" to her. He declares his love for her is "all over" and that only "the remains, the fragments, the appearance" matter.

Just then, a second letter arrives from Krogstad. Helmer reads it and shouts with joy, exclaiming, "I am saved! Nora, I am saved!" He reveals Krogstad has sent back Nora's bond, regretting his actions due to a "happy change in his life." Helmer tears up the bond and both letters, burning them in the stove, declaring, "now it doesn’t exist any longer." He then "forgives" Nora, attributing her actions to "womanly helplessness" and lack of understanding, and promises to protect her, saying she has become "both wife and child to him."

Nora, in her everyday dress, returns to confront Helmer. She states this is their first serious conversation in eight years of marriage. She tells him he has never understood her, and she has never understood him until tonight. She asserts that she has been "greatly wronged," first by her father and then by him, having been treated like a "doll-child" and a "doll-wife," living merely to "perform tricks" and adopting his tastes. She declares she has never been happy, only merry, and their home has been a "playroom."

Nora tells Helmer he is "not the man to educate me into being a proper wife for you" and that she is "not fit" to bring up the children. She announces she is leaving him and the children to "educate myself" and "understand myself and everything about me." Helmer forbids her, reminding her of her "most sacred duties" to her husband and children. Nora counters that she has "other duties just as sacred"—duties to herself. She no longer believes she is primarily a wife and mother, but a "reasonable human being" who must think for herself. She questions the law and religion, finding them illogical if they condemn saving a father or husband.

Helmer accuses her of being ill or out of her mind, but Nora states her mind has never been clearer and confirms she no longer loves him. She explains that the "wonderful thing" she hoped for—Helmer sacrificing his honor for her—did not happen. Instead, when the threat was over, he acted as if nothing had happened, treating her as his "little skylark, your doll," which made her realize she had been living with a "strange man" for eight years. She rejects his offer to live like "brother and sister."

Nora returns her wedding ring and takes back hers, declaring both of them free from all obligations. She states she will not see the children, believing they are in better hands. She refuses any future contact or help from Helmer, calling him a "stranger." She concludes that for their life together to be a "real wedlock," both would have to change so much that she no longer believes in such "wonderful things." Nora leaves the house, and the sound of a door shutting is heard from below. Helmer is left alone, pondering "The most wonderful thing of all—?"

summary_llm:
Alice, growing tired of sitting idly by her sister on a riverbank, notices a White Rabbit with pink eyes, wearing a waistcoat, taking a watch from its pocket, and exclaiming, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" Driven by curiosity, Alice follows the Rabbit down a large rabbit-hole.

She falls for a long time down what feels like a very deep well, passing cupboards, bookshelves, maps, and pictures. She retrieves an empty jar of "ORANGE MARMALADE" from a shelf and places it in another cupboard. During her descent, she muses about her location and talks to herself about her cat, Dinah. She eventually lands, unhurt, on a pile of sticks and dry leaves.

Alice sees the White Rabbit again, hurrying down a passage, still muttering about being late. She follows it into a long, low hall lined with many locked doors. On a small glass table, she finds a tiny golden key. The key is too small for the main doors, but she discovers a small door, about fifteen inches high, hidden behind a curtain. The golden key fits this lock, and Alice opens it to reveal a beautiful garden. However, she is too large to fit through the doorway.

Returning to the table, Alice finds a bottle labeled "DRINK ME." After prudently checking that it is not marked "poison," she drinks the liquid, which tastes like a mixture of various foods. She begins to shrink rapidly, becoming only ten inches high. Delighted at first, she then realizes she left the golden key on the table and cannot reach it. She sits down and cries, creating a large pool of tears around her.

The White Rabbit reappears, splendidly dressed, carrying white kid gloves and a fan, hurrying and muttering about the Duchess. Alice timidly asks for help, startling the Rabbit, who drops his items and flees. Alice picks up the fan and gloves. As she fans herself, she begins to shrink again. She realizes the fan is causing her to diminish and quickly drops it, narrowly avoiding disappearing entirely, and finds herself about two feet tall. She rushes back to the little door, but it is shut, and the key is still on the unreachable table.

Her foot slips, and she falls into the pool of tears she had wept, now swimming in salt water. She encounters a Mouse and attempts to converse with it, first in English, then in French ("Où est ma chatte?"), which offends the Mouse due to the mention of "cat." Alice apologizes but then inadvertently praises her own cat, Dinah, for catching mice, further upsetting the Mouse. She tries to change the subject to dogs, but again mentions their rat-killing abilities, causing the Mouse to swim away in a commotion. Alice calls it back, promising not to mention cats or dogs. The Mouse returns, agreeing to tell its history once they reach the shore.

The pool becomes crowded with other animals and birds (a Duck, a Dodo, a Lory, an Eaglet, and others) who have also fallen in. Alice leads them to the bank. The group is all wet and uncomfortable. The Mouse attempts to dry them by reciting a "driest thing" (a history lesson about William the Conqueror), but it fails to dry them and is interrupted by the other animals. The Dodo then proposes a "Caucus-race" as a more effective remedy. The race involves running in a circle, starting and stopping whenever one likes. After about half an hour, when everyone is dry, the Dodo declares that "Everybody has won, and all must have prizes." Alice is designated to distribute the prizes, giving each creature a comfit from her pocket. For her own prize, the Dodo solemnly presents Alice with her own thimble.

The party then asks the Mouse to tell its history, specifically why it hates "C and D" (cats and dogs). The Mouse begins a "long and a sad tale," which Alice visualizes as a poem printed in the shape of a long tail. Alice's interruptions and misinterpretations ("knot" for "not") offend the Mouse, who walks away. Alice mentions her cat, Dinah, again, praising her hunting skills, which causes all the other birds and animals to flee in fear, leaving Alice alone and sad.

Soon, the White Rabbit returns, frantically searching for his lost fan and gloves and muttering about the Duchess and execution. He mistakes Alice for his housemaid, Mary Ann, and orders her to fetch a new pair of gloves and a fan from his house. Alice, frightened, obeys and finds the Rabbit's house. Inside, she finds a fan and gloves. She also sees a bottle and, hoping to grow larger, drinks from it. She grows rapidly, her head hitting the ceiling, then she has to kneel, and eventually, she is so large she has one arm out the window and one foot up the chimney, completely stuck.

The Rabbit arrives outside, calling for Mary Ann. He tries to open the door, but Alice's elbow blocks it. He decides to enter through the window. Alice snatches at him through the window, causing a shriek, a fall, and broken glass. The Rabbit calls for "Pat" (another voice), who identifies Alice's arm in the window. The Rabbit orders Pat to remove the arm. Alice snatches again, causing more shrieks and broken glass. A rumbling of cartwheels and voices indicates a plan to use ladders and send "Bill" the Lizard down the chimney. Alice kicks her foot down the chimney, sending Bill flying out. The Rabbit suggests burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set her cat Dinah on them, causing a momentary silence. Pebbles are thrown in the window, which turn into little cakes on the floor. Alice eats one, hoping to shrink, and she does. As soon as she is small enough, she runs out of the house, escaping the crowd of animals and birds (including Bill the Lizard, who is being revived).

Alice finds herself in a thick wood, planning to return to her proper size and find the garden. She encounters an enormous puppy, which frightens her. She plays with it using a stick to distract it, then escapes when it rests. She realizes she needs to eat or drink something to grow or shrink. She finds a large mushroom and, looking over its edge, sees a large blue Caterpillar smoking a hookah.

The Caterpillar questions Alice's identity, to which Alice replies she hardly knows, having changed sizes so many times. They argue about the nature of change. The Caterpillar asks Alice to recite "You are old, Father William," but Alice recites a distorted version. The Caterpillar declares it "wrong from beginning to end." It then asks Alice what size she wants to be. Alice expresses a desire to be a little larger than her current three inches, which offends the Caterpillar (who is exactly three inches tall). The Caterpillar eventually crawls away, but not before telling Alice that one side of the mushroom will make her grow taller and the other side will make her grow shorter. Alice breaks off a piece from each side. She nibbles the right-hand bit and shrinks so rapidly her chin hits her foot. She then eats some of the left-hand bit, and her head becomes free, but her neck extends to an immense length. A large Pigeon flies into her face, screaming "Serpent!" and accuses her of trying to steal its eggs. Alice protests that she is a "little girl," but the Pigeon insists she is a serpent if she eats eggs. Alice, tired of the argument, uses the mushroom pieces to carefully adjust her size until she returns to her "usual height." She then sees a small house and decides to shrink herself to nine inches before approaching it.

Alice observes a Fish-Footman deliver a croquet invitation from the Queen to a Frog-Footman, who then sits staring blankly. Alice enters the house and finds a smoky kitchen where the Duchess is nursing a constantly sneezing and howling baby, while a Cook stirs a peppery soup. A Cheshire Cat grins on the hearth. Alice asks why the cat grins, and the Duchess explains it's a Cheshire cat. The Cook begins throwing kitchen items at the Duchess and baby. The Duchess sings a violent lullaby to the baby, then flings it at Alice, telling her to nurse it while she goes to play croquet. Alice struggles to hold the oddly shaped, grunting baby. She carries it outside, fearing for its safety, and observes its pig-like features. The baby eventually turns into a pig, and Alice sets it down, watching it trot away into the wood.

Alice then encounters the Cheshire Cat sitting on a tree bough. She asks it which way to go. The Cat replies it depends on where she wants to get, and that everyone there, including the Hatter and March Hare, is mad. The Cat explains its own madness by saying it growls when pleased and wags its tail when angry. The Cat asks if Alice will play croquet with the Queen and then vanishes, only to reappear moments later to ask about the baby, which Alice confirms turned into a pig. The Cat vanishes again, leaving only its grin, which slowly fades. Alice proceeds towards the March Hare's house, which has unusual features like ear-shaped chimneys and a fur-thatched roof. She shrinks herself to two feet high before approaching.

Alice finds the March Hare and the Hatter having tea at a large table, with a Dormouse asleep between them, used as a cushion. They claim there's "No room!" but Alice sits down. They offer her wine, but there is none, leading to an argument about civility and meaning what you say. The Hatter asks, "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" but neither he nor the March Hare knows the answer. The Hatter checks his watch, which tells the day of the month but not the time, blaming the March Hare for putting butter in it. He explains that he and "Time" quarreled, so it's "always six o’clock" (tea-time) for them, forcing them to constantly move around the table. The Dormouse, repeatedly woken up, tells a nonsensical story about three sisters living in a "treacle-well" and drawing "treacle" and things beginning with "M." Alice questions the story, but the Hatter and March Hare are rude and dismissive. Disgusted, Alice leaves the tea-party, noting they are trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.

Alice finds a door in a tree, which leads back to the long hall. She uses the golden key and a piece of the mushroom (which she had kept) to shrink herself to about a foot high, and finally enters the beautiful garden.

In the garden, Alice sees three gardeners (shaped like playing cards) painting white roses red, explaining they planted the wrong color and fear the Queen's wrath. A grand procession arrives: soldiers, courtiers, royal children, the White Rabbit, the Knave of Hearts, and finally, the King and Queen of Hearts. Alice stands her ground when the Queen questions her. The Queen, prone to shouting "Off with her head!" orders the gardeners beheaded for painting the roses. Alice protects them by hiding them in a flower-pot. The Queen then invites Alice to play croquet.

The croquet game is chaotic: the ground is uneven, the balls are live hedgehogs, the mallets are live flamingoes, and the arches are doubled-up soldiers who constantly move. The Queen frequently shouts "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" Alice feels uneasy and looks for an escape. The Cheshire Cat's grin appears in the air, followed by its head. Alice complains to the Cat about the unfair game. The King, curious, asks Alice about the Cat. The Queen, without looking, orders the Cat's head removed. An argument ensues between the executioner, the King, and the Queen about how to behead a head without a body. Alice suggests asking the Duchess, who is in prison. As the executioner leaves to fetch the Duchess, the Cat's head fades away and disappears entirely.

The Duchess returns, linking arms with Alice and speaking affectionately, constantly finding morals in everything. The Queen reappears, angrily confronts the Duchess, and orders her to choose between leaving or losing her head. The Duchess immediately vanishes. The Queen then asks Alice if she has seen the Mock Turtle. Alice says no, so the Queen takes her to meet him, leaving Alice with a Gryphon. The Gryphon reveals that the Queen's execution threats are "all her fancy" and "they never executes nobody."

They find the Mock Turtle, who is sitting sadly and sighing. The Gryphon again states his sorrow is "all his fancy." The Mock Turtle, with tears, begins to tell his history, explaining he was once a "real Turtle" and went to school in the sea, learning "Reeling and Writhing," "Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision," and "Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils." He also mentions that lessons "lessen" from day to day. The Gryphon interrupts, suggesting they talk about games.

The Mock Turtle describes the "Lobster Quadrille," a dance involving lobsters, swimming, and somersaults. He and the Gryphon demonstrate the first figure of the dance and the Mock Turtle sings a song about a whiting and a snail. They explain that whitings have their tails in their mouths because they were thrown out to sea, and that under the sea, shoes are made shiny with a "whiting" and are made of "Soles and eels." The Mock Turtle insists wise fish always go with a "porpoise" (mispronouncing "purpose"). The Gryphon then asks Alice to tell her adventures. Alice recounts her experiences from that morning, including her size changes and her incorrect recitation of "You are old, Father William" to the Caterpillar. The Mock Turtle and Gryphon find her story curious and ask her to recite another poem. Alice recites a nonsensical version of "’Tis the voice of the Lobster," which confuses her listeners. The Gryphon then suggests the Mock Turtle sing a song. The Mock Turtle sings a melancholy song called "Turtle Soup."

Suddenly, a cry of "The trial’s beginning!" is heard. The Gryphon takes Alice by the hand, and they hurry off to the trial.

They arrive to find the King and Queen of Hearts on their throne, with a crowd of creatures and cards. The Knave of Hearts is in chains, accused of stealing the Queen's tarts, which are displayed on a table. The White Rabbit acts as the Herald. The King is the judge, and twelve "creatures" (animals and birds) serve as the jury, busily writing on slates. Alice takes away Bill the Lizard's squeaking pencil. The White Rabbit reads the accusation.

The first witness is the Hatter, who gives rambling, nonsensical testimony about tea-time, conflicting dates, and the "twinkling of the tea." During his testimony, Alice begins to grow larger again, causing the Dormouse (who is also present) to complain and move away. The King threatens the Hatter with execution if he doesn't provide clearer evidence. The Hatter is dismissed, and the Queen orders his head off, but he escapes.

The second witness is the Duchess's Cook, who carries a pepper-box, causing everyone to sneeze. She refuses to give evidence. When cross-examined by the King, she states tarts are made of "Pepper, mostly." The Dormouse, speaking from behind her, interjects "Treacle." The Queen, enraged, orders the Dormouse to be beheaded and removed. In the ensuing confusion, the Cook disappears.

To Alice's surprise, the White Rabbit then calls "Alice!" as the next witness. Forgetting her size, Alice jumps up, tipping over the jury-box and spilling the jurymen. She hastily puts them back, ensuring Bill the Lizard is right-side up. The King asks Alice what she knows about the business, and she replies, "Nothing whatever." The King declares this "very important," but the White Rabbit corrects him to "Unimportant," which the King then adopts.

The King, consulting his notebook, reads "Rule Forty-two: _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_." Everyone looks at Alice, who is now very large. Alice denies being a mile high, but the King and Queen insist she is. Alice refuses to leave, arguing the rule was just invented. The King, flustered, tells the jury to consider their verdict.

The White Rabbit interrupts, presenting a newly found paper—a set of unsigned, nonsensical verses, supposedly written by the prisoner. The King and Queen interpret the verses as proof of the Knave's guilt. Alice, now grown to her full size and unafraid, loudly declares there's "not an atom of meaning in it." The King attempts to find meaning in the verses, making a pun about the word "fit" and the Queen's "fits."

The King again calls for a verdict. The Queen, however, demands, "Sentence first—verdict afterwards." Alice calls this "Stuff and nonsense!" and refuses to hold her tongue when the Queen orders it. The Queen screams, "Off with her head!" Alice, at her full height, retorts, "Who cares for you? You’re nothing but a pack of cards!"

At this, the entire pack of cards rises into the air and flies down upon her. Alice screams and tries to beat them off, and then finds herself lying on the riverbank, with her head in her sister's lap. Her sister wakes her, asking about her long sleep. Alice recounts her "curious dream" to her sister. Her sister, after listening, kisses her and tells her to go for tea. Alice runs off, thinking about her wonderful dream.

Alice's sister remains on the bank, leaning her head on her hand, and begins to dream herself, picturing Alice's adventures: the White Rabbit, the frightened Mouse, the tea-party with the March Hare and his friends, the Queen's shrill cries, the pig-baby, the Gryphon, the Lizard's pencil, the suppressed guinea-pigs, and the Mock Turtle's sobs. She imagines how these strange sounds would transform into the ordinary sounds of a farmyard if she were to open her eyes. Finally, she pictures Alice as a grown woman, sharing these strange tales with other children, keeping her childhood heart, and finding joy in their simple pleasures, remembering her own happy summer days.

summary_llm:
The provided text, "Anna Karenina," details the intertwined lives of several characters, primarily focusing on the Oblonsky family, Konstantin Levin, and Anna Karenina herself, through a series of events, internal reflections, and social interactions.

**PART ONE**

The story begins in the **Oblonskys' house**, where "everything was in confusion." The wife, **Darya Alexandrovna (Dolly)**, has discovered her husband, **Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva)**, is having an affair with their French governess. Dolly has declared she can no longer live with him, causing three days of painful tension for the entire household, including the children, governess, housekeeper, cook, and other staff.

Stepan Arkadyevitch wakes up in his study, not his wife's room, recalling a pleasant dream. He then remembers the "hopelessness of his position" and his own fault, particularly an "idiotic smile" he gave when Dolly confronted him with the incriminating letter. He despairs, wondering what to do. He admits to himself that he doesn't regret his infidelity, only failing to hide it. He feels sorry for his wife and children.

His valet, Matvey, brings him a telegram. Matvey, an old friend, hints at Stepan's financial difficulties and reveals that Stepan's sister, **Anna Arkadyevna**, will arrive tomorrow. Matvey believes Anna's arrival might bring about a reconciliation between Stepan and Dolly. Dolly, however, has already told Matvey she is leaving and Stepan can do as he likes. Matrona Philimonovna, the nurse, urges Stepan to beg Dolly's forgiveness for the children's sake, but Dolly refuses to see him.

Stepan, despite his unhappiness, feels physically at ease. He reads letters, including an "unpleasant" one about selling a forest on his wife's property, which is financially necessary but cannot be discussed with Dolly yet. He reads a liberal newspaper, aligning his views with the majority. His children, Grisha and Tanya, come to greet him. Tanya, his favorite, blushes when he asks about her mother, revealing her awareness of the quarrel. Stepan gives them sweets. He then attends to a petitioner, a widow, offering her advice and a note of recommendation. He contemplates speaking to Dolly but an inner voice tells him it's useless, as he cannot make her attractive again or himself less susceptible to love. He decides he must go to her anyway.

Dolly is in her bedroom, trying to sort her and the children's belongings to move to her mother's. She feels she must leave but knows it's impossible due to her love for Stepan and the practical difficulties of caring for five children alone. Stepan enters, timidly calling her name. His radiant health contrasts with her worn appearance, making her resent his "disgusting good nature." She asks what he wants. He tells her Anna is coming. Dolly refuses to see Anna and shrieks at him to "Go away!" Stepan is moved to tears by her despair. He begs forgiveness, offering to do "anything" for the children. Dolly calls him "Stiva" but recoils from his touch. She questions how they can live together after his affair with the governess, calling him "loathsome" and "repulsive." A child's cry softens her face. Dolly threatens to expose him to the servants and children as a "scoundrel" and leaves, slamming the door. Stepan is mortified by her "vulgarly" shouted words. He instructs Matvey to prepare a room for Anna. Dolly, alone, still wonders if Stepan has ended the affair, but feels reconciliation is impossible, and they are "strangers forever." She drowns her grief in daily duties.

Stepan Arkadyevitch holds a lucrative government post, obtained through his brother-in-law, **Alexey Alexandrovitch Karenin** (Anna's husband). He is well-liked in society and at work due to his good humor, liberalism, and indifference to business. At his office, he conducts a board meeting. His old friend, **Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin**, arrives. Levin is a country gentleman, cattle-breeder, and sportsman, and brother of Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev. Levin is shy and irritable, having resigned from district council work, which he found ineffective or corrupt. He wants to know about the **Shtcherbatskys**, specifically **Kitty**, with whom he is in love. Stepan, knowing this, suggests they meet later after Levin sees Kitty at the Zoological Gardens, where she skates. Stepan sighs, admitting his own affairs are "in a poor way."

Levin has come to Moscow to propose to Kitty. He has long admired the Shtcherbatsky family. After two months of enchantment in Moscow, he decided he was unworthy of Kitty and returned to the country. He felt he had no definite career, unlike his successful contemporaries, and considered himself an "ugly, good-natured man." However, in the country, he realized his love for Kitty was not a passing passion and he couldn't live without her. He returned to Moscow determined to propose.

Levin stays with his half-brother, **Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev**, a well-known author. Sergey is engaged in a philosophical debate with a professor about psychological and physiological phenomena. Levin finds their discussion avoids the "meaning of life and death." He asks if existence is possible without a body, but his question is dismissed.

After the professor leaves, Sergey asks about Levin's farming and district council work. Levin explains his resignation, criticizing the councils. Sergey reveals their brother, **Nikolay**, a ruined and dissolute man, is in Moscow. Levin is horrified and wants to see him, despite Sergey's advice against it and Nikolay's note asking to be left alone. Levin decides to visit Nikolay later, but first goes to Oblonsky's office for news of the Shtcherbatskys, then to find Kitty.

At the Zoological Gardens, Levin sees Kitty skating. He is overwhelmed by her beauty and feels she is unapproachable. Kitty, recognizing him, smiles and suggests they skate together. Levin is ecstatic. As they skate, holding hands, she expresses confidence in him. He replies, "And I have confidence in myself when you are leaning on me," then blushes. Her face loses its friendliness. She suggests he speak to Mlle. Linon, her old governess. Levin feels he has offended her. He speaks to Mlle. Linon, who reminds him of his old joke about the three sisters. When he returns to Kitty, her friendliness is "deliberate composure." He says his stay depends on her. She skates away. Levin is horrified. He sees Kitty and her mother leaving. The Princess stiffly invites him to their Thursday at-home. Kitty, softening her mother's coldness, says "Good-bye till this evening." Stepan Arkadyevitch arrives and takes Levin to dinner.

At the restaurant, Levin is uncomfortable. Stepan orders an elaborate meal. Levin criticizes city life, and Stepan calls him a "savage." Stepan reveals Kitty is in love with Vronsky, and her mother supports him. Stepan says his wife, Dolly, has a gift for "foreseeing things" and believes "Kitty is certain to be your wife." Levin is overjoyed, confessing his past "sins" and feeling unworthy. Stepan dismisses his sins.

Stepan then tells Levin that Vronsky is his rival, describing him as wealthy, handsome, and intelligent. Levin is angered, feeling his sacred feelings are "profaned." Stepan asks for advice on his own infidelity. Levin dismisses "fallen women." Stepan argues that life is not "all of a piece." Levin, absorbed in his own affairs, doesn't hear. They feel distant. Stepan leaves to talk to an aide-de-camp. Levin pays his expensive share of the bill and leaves to dress for the Shtcherbatskys'.

Kitty, eighteen, is a great success in society, with two serious suitors: Levin and Vronsky. The Princess prefers Vronsky, disliking Levin's shyness and country life. Vronsky is wealthy, clever, and aristocratic. The Princess is anxious about marrying off her daughters, noting changes in society where girls choose their own husbands. She fears Vronsky might only flirt. Kitty told her Vronsky awaits his mother's arrival before proposing. Levin's reappearance causes new anxiety for the Princess, fearing Kitty might refuse Vronsky out of honor. Kitty, returning home, asks her mother not to speak of it, though she desires what her mother desires.

Kitty feels the evening will be a turning point. She recalls Levin's tender love but finds the future with Vronsky "brilliant happiness." She enters the ballroom, feeling beautiful and confident. Levin arrives early, finding her alone. She realizes he has come to propose and she will have to "wound" him. She decides to tell the truth. Levin proposes, "to be my wife!" Kitty feels ecstasy, then remembers Vronsky, and hastily refuses him, "That cannot be ... forgive me." Levin says, "It was bound to be so." The Princess enters, relieved. Countess Nordston teases Levin. Vronsky arrives, greeting Kitty with "tender light" and a "modestly triumphant smile." Levin sees in Kitty's eyes that she loves Vronsky. Conversation turns to spiritualism, which Levin dismisses. Vronsky suggests table-turning. Kitty's eyes meet Levin's, expressing pity and happiness. Levin feels hatred. The old Prince embraces Levin, not noticing Vronsky. Levin leaves unnoticed, his last impression being Kitty's "smiling, happy face" answering Vronsky about the ball.

Kitty tells her mother about Levin's offer and her refusal, feeling she acted rightly but is haunted by Levin's "dark dejection." Her happiness is "poisoned by doubts." The Prince and Princess argue; the Prince blames the Princess for pushing Vronsky and praises Levin. The Princess is disturbed.

Vronsky, having no real home life, enjoyed the intimacy with Kitty. He didn't think his behavior was harmful and didn't consider marriage. He felt a stronger bond with Kitty after the evening and believed she loved him. He goes home and sleeps.

Next morning, Vronsky meets Oblonsky at the railway station. Oblonsky teases Vronsky about being in love. Vronsky asks whom Oblonsky is meeting, learning it's Anna Karenina. Vronsky has a vague, tedious recollection of her. Oblonsky tells Vronsky about Levin's proposal to Kitty and her likely refusal. Vronsky thinks Kitty could do better. A railway guard is crushed by a train. Anna is agitated, calling it an "omen of evil." Vronsky immediately gives 200 roubles for the widow. Anna asks about Vronsky and Kitty. Oblonsky says they hope Vronsky will marry Kitty. Anna leaves with Oblonsky, feeling the accident is an "omen of evil."

Vronsky, seeing Anna, is struck by her "caressing and soft" expression. He feels "joyful pride." He enters his mother's carriage. His mother, Countess Vronskaya, greets him and mentions Anna has an eight-year-old son and is fretting. She also implies Vronsky is having a "perfect love affair." Anna embraces her brother. Vronsky watches, smiling. Anna says good-bye to the Countess, who praises her. Anna gives Vronsky her hand, and he is delighted by her "energetic squeeze." Vronsky watches Anna leave, feeling annoyed she's talking eagerly about something not concerning him.

**PART TWO**

Kitty's health declines. Doctors suggest going abroad. The celebrated physician diagnoses "nervous irritability" and prescribes Soden waters. The family doctor suggests foreign travel to escape "reminiscences." Kitty, dazed with shame, feels her heart is "broken." She agrees to go abroad.

Dolly arrives, having just given birth and with a sick child. She is worried about Kitty. Her own life with Stepan is humiliating due to his infidelity and financial issues. The Prince blames the Princess for pushing Vronsky on Kitty, calling Vronsky a "peacock" and praising Levin. Kitty, hearing her father, bursts into tears, feeling he understands her shame. Dolly tells her mother Levin had intended to propose. Dolly goes to Kitty, who, in a "passion," lashes out at Dolly for her "sympathizing" and for going back to a man who deceived her. Kitty then sobs, saying she is "so, so wretched!" They reconcile. Kitty confesses everything is "hateful, loathsome, coarse" to her. She insists on staying with Dolly to nurse the children through scarlatina. Kitty's health does not improve, and the Shtcherbatskys go abroad.

Anna, in Petersburg, now avoids her husband's official circle and Countess Lidia Ivanovna's intellectual set, finding them insincere. She gravitates to Princess Betsy Tverskaya's fashionable world, where she frequently meets Vronsky. She realizes Vronsky's pursuit is the "whole interest of her life." At the theater, Betsy teases Vronsky about being "caught" by Anna. Vronsky admits it. He tells Betsy he was mediating a scandal involving Petritsky and a government clerk.

Anna enters Betsy's drawing-room. She and Vronsky exchange glances. Anna tells Vronsky Kitty is very ill. She tells him he behaved "wrongly" with Kitty. Vronsky asks who was to blame. Anna, blushing, forbids him to speak of "love." She says "this must end" and asks him to go to Moscow to ask Kitty's forgiveness. Vronsky says she is "all my life" and he cannot find peace without her. He sees "despair, of wretchedness ... or ... bliss." She looks at him with love, but says they must be friends. He says they will never be friends. Alexey Alexandrovitch enters. Anna stays for supper. Vronsky escorts her out, murmuring "love!" Anna says the word "means too much to me."

Alexey Alexandrovitch, noticing the impropriety, decides to speak to Anna. He paces, feeling a "chasm" in his "artificial life." He plans a speech about public opinion, religious marriage, their son, and her unhappiness. Anna enters, feigning innocence. He warns her about her "too animated conversation" with Vronsky. Anna pretends to misunderstand. He coldly states she disregarded "rules of decorum." She tries to leave. He stops her, his face "ugly and forbidding." He says their union is from God and can only be severed by "crime." Anna feigns sleepiness. He says he loves her. Anna thinks he doesn't know what love is. He asks her to speak out if she feels any foundation for his words. She says she has nothing to say. He goes to bed. Anna lies awake, thinking of Vronsky with "guilty delight." She has a recurring nightmare of both men being her husbands.

Alexey Alexandrovitch and Anna's inner relations change, though outwardly they remain the same. He feels helpless against her "amused perplexity." He tries to talk to her but always uses a sarcastic tone.

Vronsky's desire for Anna is fulfilled. Anna, feeling "sinful, so guilty," sinks to his feet, sobbing, begging forgiveness. Vronsky feels like a murderer. He covers her with kisses. She says, "All is over; I have nothing but you." She says "Happiness!" with "horror and loathing." She pushes him away, saying "Not a word more." She cannot express her complex feelings. She has a recurring nightmare about both men being her husbands.

Levin, three months after his rejection, still feels the pain. He learns his brother Nikolay is ill and goes to Moscow to persuade him to go abroad. Levin is working on a book about agriculture. Spring arrives, and Levin feels renewed. He goes to his farm, finds slovenliness, gets angry, then mows with the peasants, finding joy in the work. He dines with an old peasant, feeling closer to him than to his brother. He sees Ivan Parmenov and his wife, observing their "freshly awakened love." He feels envious of their "laborious, pure, and socially delightful life." He muses on his own life, deciding his old dreams were "absurd." He sees Kitty in a carriage, driving to Ergushovo. He realizes, "I cannot go back to it. I love _her_."

Levin asks Stepan about Kitty's illness. Stepan reveals she is "very ill" and doctors fear she may not live. Levin is shocked, but also pleased she is suffering. Stepan sells his forest to Ryabinin for a low price, which Levin criticizes as a "fraud." Levin argues about the impoverishment of the nobility and his own aristocratic values. Stepan says Vronsky is in Petersburg and Levin's rejection was his "own fault." Levin confesses his rejection.

Vronsky, after his fall and Anna's confession, feels "disgraced, humiliated, guilty." He feels his passion for Anna is stronger than ever. He considers suicide, takes a revolver, and shoots himself in the chest, but misses his heart. His brother's wife, Varya, nurses him.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, at Anna's sickbed, experiences "spiritual peace" from pity, remorse, and the "joy of forgiveness." He forgives Anna and Vronsky, and feels tenderness for the newborn baby, not his own. He is disturbed by society's expectations and Anna's fear of him. He overhears Betsy discussing Vronsky's suicide attempt. Anna, flushing, tells him Vronsky wants to say good-bye before going to Tashkend, and she refused to see him. Alexey Alexandrovitch is confused, unable to discuss it before Betsy. Betsy advises him to receive Vronsky. Alexey Alexandrovitch tells Anna she must decide.

Alexey Alexandrovitch goes to Anna, who is crying. He thanks her for her decision not to see Vronsky. Anna is irritated, wanting him to leave. She blames him for not letting her nurse the baby. She bursts into sobs, wishing she had died. Alexey Alexandrovitch decides their situation "can’t go on like this." He feels helpless against society's expectations.

Stepan Arkadyevitch meets Betsy, who says Alexey Alexandrovitch is "killing her" (Anna) and suggests divorce. Stepan agrees. He goes to Anna, who says she hates her husband for his "virtues" and cannot live with him. Stepan soothes her, suggesting divorce. Anna shakes her head, but her face brightens. Stepan offers to arrange it.

Stepan goes to Alexey Alexandrovitch, who gives him an unfinished letter to Anna, offering to forget the past and start a new life. Stepan suggests divorce. Alexey Alexandrovitch is averse, citing religious scruples, the illegitimacy of his son, and his desire to punish Anna. He feels divorce would ruin Anna. He says he will take the disgrace on himself, even give up his son. Stepan is touched. Alexey Alexandrovitch says he needs time to think.

Seryozha, Alexey Alexandrovitch's son, talks to the hall-porter about his father's new order. He struggles with his lessons, disbelieves in death, and prays for his mother to come for his birthday. Anna, having received a cruel refusal from Lidia Ivanovna to see Seryozha, decides to go to Alexey Alexandrovitch's house. She bribes the servants and enters Seryozha's room. He embraces her, saying he knew she would come. Anna is choked with tears. The servants try to prevent Alexey Alexandrovitch from meeting Anna. Anna tells Seryozha to love his father, saying "he’s better and kinder than I am." Alexey Alexandrovitch enters. Anna runs out, filled with "repulsion and hatred" for him. She leaves the toys she bought for Seryozha.

Anna returns to her hotel room, distraught. She feels her love for her baby daughter is not "love" compared to Seryozha. She looks at Seryozha's photograph, then Vronsky's, realizing he is the cause of her misery. She feels he is growing cold. She dresses with extra care. Yashvin and Vronsky arrive. Anna snatches Seryozha's photos from Vronsky. She invites Yashvin to dinner. She asks Vronsky if he has changed. He says his feelings cannot change, but he is cold.

Vronsky feels anger at Anna's willful refusal to understand her position. He thinks her public appearance is a "challenge to society." He returns to his rooms. Anna's valet announces she has gone to the theater. Vronsky goes to the theater, where he sees Madame Kartasova insult Anna. His mother also makes sarcastic remarks. Anna is distressed. She cries to Vronsky, "You, you are to blame for everything!" She tells him about her dream of dying in childbirth. They reconcile. Vronsky declines the Tashkend appointment and retires from the army. Anna and Vronsky go abroad without a divorce.

**PART THREE**

Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev visits his brother, Konstantin Levin, in the country. Levin is uncomfortable with Sergey's intellectualized view of country life and peasants, preferring his own practical, hands-on approach. Sergey criticizes Levin's lack of participation in public affairs. Levin argues that his personal interests don't align with these public duties.

Levin decides to mow with the peasants, finding joy and a sense of belonging in the physical labor. He has a deep conversation with an old peasant, Fokanitch, who says he lives "for his soul, in truth, in God’s way." This sparks a profound spiritual awakening in Levin. He realizes that true knowledge comes not from reason but from intuitive faith in goodness, a truth shared by all people. He feels a "new and important" thing has happened to him, giving his life "positive meaning."

Levin's brother Nikolay, who is dying of consumption, comes to stay with him. Levin is horrified by Nikolay's emaciated state but is also filled with pity. Nikolay, in his irritability, quarrels with Levin, accusing him of distorting communist ideas. Levin, in turn, is frustrated by Nikolay's cynicism and self-deception. Kitty joins Levin to nurse Nikolay, showing remarkable compassion and practical skill. She takes charge of his care, making him comfortable and persuading him to receive extreme unction. Nikolay temporarily rallies, but then declines rapidly. He dies, uttering "Right!" and "O Lord!" Levin is filled with horror at the enigma of death, but his wife's presence and the news of her pregnancy (a new mystery of life) save him from despair.

**PART FOUR**

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's confession, feels relief, like a tooth has been pulled. He decides Anna is a "corrupt woman" and focuses on extricating himself from the situation with "propriety and comfort." He considers dueling, divorce, and separation, but rejects them all due to his cowardice, fear of scandal, and unwillingness to see Anna free or to be blamed for her ruin. He decides to keep her with him, concealing the affair, breaking off the intrigue, and punishing her. He writes a letter to Anna, stating their life must go on as before and she must return to Petersburg. He finds religious justification for his decision.

Anna, after confessing to her husband, feels her position is "false and dishonorable." She regrets her words, fears disgrace, and the loss of Seryozha. She decides to take Seryozha and leave. She writes a letter to her husband, but tears it up, then rewrites it without an appeal to his generosity. She tries to write to Vronsky but finds it "coarse." She decides to go to Betsy's, hoping to see Vronsky. At Betsy's, she writes a note to Vronsky, asking him to meet her in the Vrede garden.

Vronsky, after his fall in the steeplechase, feels disgraced and humiliated. He attempts suicide by shooting himself but only wounds himself. His brother's wife, Varya, nurses him. Alexey Alexandrovitch, at Anna's sickbed, experiences a "blissful spiritual condition" of forgiveness. He forgives Anna and Vronsky. He feels tenderness for the newborn baby, not his own. He decides to keep Anna with him. Countess Lidia Ivanovna, who is in love with Karenin, tries to prevent Anna from seeing Seryozha. She sends Anna a letter, refusing her request. Anna, enraged, decides to go directly to Alexey Alexandrovitch's house on Seryozha's birthday. She bribes the servants and sees Seryozha. They embrace. Anna tells Seryozha to love his father. Alexey Alexandrovitch enters. Anna runs out, filled with "repulsion and hatred" for him.

Anna returns to her hotel, distraught. She feels Vronsky is growing cold. She dresses with care. Vronsky arrives with Yashvin. Anna snatches Seryozha's photographs from Vronsky. She invites Yashvin to dinner. She asks Vronsky if he has changed. He is cold. Vronsky is angry at Anna's public defiance. He goes to the theater, where he sees Madame Kartasova insult Anna. He goes to Anna, who blames him for everything. She tells him about her dream of dying in childbirth. They reconcile. Vronsky declines a prestigious appointment and retires from the army. Anna and Vronsky go abroad without a divorce.

**PART FIVE**

Levin and Kitty are married. Kitty is pregnant. Levin is in a "delirious condition" of happiness, letting others manage wedding preparations. He is surprised Kitty has definite plans for their country home. He is forced to go to confession, which he finds hypocritical, but does so to marry Kitty. At confession, he expresses his doubts about God, but the priest reassures him. On the wedding day, Levin is frantic because his clean shirt was packed. He rushes to the church. Kitty is pale but beautiful. They exchange vows. Kitty is absorbed in the "joy at the completion" of her new life. Levin feels his ideas of marriage are "childishness." He is moved to tears. They kiss. After supper, they leave for the country.

Vronsky and Anna travel in Europe. Vronsky meets an old comrade, Golenishtchev, and introduces him to Anna. Golenishtchev is struck by Anna's beauty and frankness. Vronsky is bored with his aimless life and takes up painting, particularly Anna's portrait. He also buys a picture by the Russian artist Mihailov. Mihailov paints Anna's portrait, which is a great success. Vronsky tries to paint too, but his efforts are inferior. Vronsky's interest in painting wanes. They find their Italian life tedious and decide to return to Russia, planning to live on Vronsky's estate. Anna wants to see Seryozha.

Levin and Kitty's married life begins with "disappointments" and "happy surprises." They quarrel frequently over trivial matters, but always reconcile. Levin realizes he and Kitty are one. He works on his book about agriculture, blaming "civilization from without" for Russia's problems. Kitty is absorbed in setting up their home. Levin is initially critical of her domesticity but comes to admire it. Marya Nikolaevna writes to Levin that his brother Nikolay is dying. Levin and Kitty go to him. Kitty takes charge of Nikolay's care, showing great compassion. Nikolay dies, finding peace at the end. The doctor confirms Kitty is pregnant.

**PART SIX**

Dolly and her children spend the summer at Pokrovskoe with Kitty and Levin. Varenka, Kitty's friend, also stays. Levin feels his "Levin world" is "smothered" by the "Shtcherbatsky element." Sergey Ivanovitch expresses interest in Varenka, and Kitty hopes for a match. Levin, Kitty, and the children go mushroom picking. Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka walk alone, but Sergey hesitates to propose, asking about mushrooms instead. Varenka is disappointed but relieved. Sergey Ivanovitch decides he cannot be false to his deceased first love.

Stepan Arkadyevitch visits the Levins, bringing Vassenka Veslovsky, a charming but frivolous young man. Levin is vexed by Vassenka's flirtation with Kitty, feeling humiliated and jealous. He confronts Kitty, who, though initially offended, confesses her love for him and soothes his fears. Levin, still angry, sends Vassenka away. Dolly and Stepan Arkadyevitch are upset by Levin's rudeness.

Dolly visits Anna at Vronsky's estate, Vozdvizhenskoe. She is impressed by the luxury and Anna's beauty, but feels uneasy about their irregular position. Vronsky confesses to Dolly his unhappiness about their illegitimate child and the lack of a legal tie. He asks Dolly to persuade Anna to seek a divorce. Anna tells Dolly she is using contraception, which shocks Dolly. Anna says she cannot have more children who would bear a stranger's name. Dolly is horrified, feeling a barrier between them. Anna, distraught, takes morphine.

**PART SEVEN**

The Levins are in Moscow for Kitty's confinement. Kitty is calm and happy, embracing her new feeling of love for her unborn child. Levin is uneasy in the city, feeling he has nothing to do and his work is muddled. He is still troubled by his unbelief. Kitty meets Vronsky at a social gathering, but remains composed and indifferent, pleasing Levin.

Levin visits his old university friend, Professor Katavasov, and meets the scientific writer Metrov. He discusses his book on agriculture, but finds their academic approach unhelpful for his practical concerns. He is bored by intellectual discussions.

Kitty's sister, Natalia Lvova, and her husband Arseny, visit. Levin admires their well-brought-up children and Lvov's dedication to their education. Levin is asked to talk to Stepan Arkadyevitch about Dolly's financial difficulties.

Levin attends a concert and a public meeting, but finds them uninteresting. He feels ashamed of his past mistakes and his lack of faith. He visits Countess Bola, then goes to the club, where he eats and drinks with Turovtsin and Gagin. Vronsky also arrives. Levin feels no hostility towards Vronsky and they chat amicably.

Levin, at the club, feels a sense of repose and comfort. Stepan Arkadyevitch suggests they visit Anna. Levin agrees. Stepan tells him Anna and Vronsky are negotiating a divorce, but there are difficulties regarding Seryozha. He describes Anna's life in Moscow, her writing a children's book, and her care for a poor English family.

Levin and Stepan visit Anna. Levin is captivated by her portrait and then by Anna herself. She is delighted to see him and speaks of Kitty. She discusses art with Vorkuev and Levin. Levin is struck by her wit, grace, beauty, and truthfulness. He feels tenderness and pity for her.

Levin returns home, still thinking of Anna. Kitty is low-spirited and jealous, accusing him of being in love with Anna. Levin confesses his pity for Anna and his own degeneration in Moscow. They reconcile.

**PART EIGHT**

Sergey Ivanovitch's book, "Sketch of a Survey of the Principles and Forms of Government in Europe and Russia," is published but receives no attention. He is disappointed. He then throws himself into the Slavonic question and the Servian War, finding a new purpose in expressing "public opinion." He travels to the country with Katavasov.

At the railway station, Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov see volunteers leaving for Servia. A princess tells Sergey Ivanovitch that Vronsky is also going by this train, taking a squadron at his own expense. Sergey Ivanovitch talks to Vronsky, who is grim and suffering, saying life is "loathsome" to him and he is going to meet death. Vronsky is still haunted by Anna's death.

Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov arrive at Levin's. Kitty is delighted. Kitty is now a mother, and her baby son, Mitya, is her greatest joy. She is fiercely protective of him. Levin is still struggling with his faith, but finds solace in his family and work. He observes the peasants, and their simple faith. He feels he has found the "Master" and a "positive meaning of goodness" in his life.

Kitty is unwell, a symptom of pregnancy. Nikolay Levin dies, finding peace in his last moments. Levin feels the "need of life and love" in the face of death.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's departure, is distraught and feels alone. Countess Lidia Ivanovna offers him moral support and turns him into an "ardent and steadfast adherent" of a new Christian doctrine, in which he believes he has achieved "complete salvation." Lidia Ivanovna intercepts Anna's letter asking to see Seryozha. Seryozha, now at school, tries to forget his mother.

Anna, in Moscow, feels Vronsky is growing cold. She is tormented by jealousy and the delay of her divorce. She has a recurring nightmare about the peasant and dying in childbirth. She confronts Vronsky, who is angered by her accusations. She threatens to die. He tries to soothe her. They reconcile. Anna writes to her husband asking for a divorce. Vronsky and Anna move to Moscow, living together as if married.

In Moscow, Anna and Vronsky's relationship becomes strained. Anna's jealousy and Vronsky's desire for independence lead to constant quarrels. Anna feels Vronsky's love is waning. She decides to end her life. She goes to the railway station, recalling the man crushed by the train when she first met Vronsky. She throws herself under a train, dying instantly.

Almost two months later, Sergey Ivanovitch reflects on the failure of his book and his new involvement in the Slavonic question. He and Katavasov travel to Levin's.

Levin is deeply affected by Anna's death. He struggles with his faith, but through his family, his work, and the simple faith of the peasants, he finds a new understanding of God and the meaning of life. He realizes that goodness is outside reason and that he must live for God, not for his own desires. He accepts that he will still struggle with his imperfections, but his life now has a "positive meaning of goodness."

The text concludes with Levin's internal realization that his new faith, though not changing him outwardly, has taken firm root in his soul, giving his life meaning and purpose. He will continue to live, work, and love, guided by this inner sense of goodness.

summary_llm:
The story begins on a hot July evening as a young man, Raskolnikov, leaves his garret in S. Place, avoiding his landlady to whom he is deeply in debt. He is impoverished, irritable, and isolated, burdened by an unspoken "thing" he intends to attempt. He counts the 730 steps to a large house, planning a "rehearsal" for his project. He enters the building via a dark back staircase, noting that a German clerk is moving out, leaving only an old woman on the fourth floor.

Raskolnikov rings the bell of the old woman, Alyona Ivanovna, a diminutive, withered pawnbroker with sharp, malignant eyes. He introduces himself as a student and pawns an old silver watch, his father's. Alyona Ivanovna is a harsh businesswoman, offering only a rouble and a half for the watch and deducting interest in advance. Raskolnikov is angered but accepts, observing her keys and deducing one large, notched key is for a strong-box. As he leaves, he casually asks if her sister, Lizaveta, is always alone.

Overwhelmed by repulsion and agitation, Raskolnikov enters a tavern. There, he encounters a drunken, retired clerk named Marmeladov, who introduces himself and begins to confess his life story. Marmeladov reveals his extreme poverty and his wife, Katerina Ivanovna, an educated officer's daughter, who is now consumptive and works tirelessly to support their three small children. He admits to selling his wife's belongings for drink and recounts how, driven by desperation, Katerina Ivanovna pushed his daughter, Sonia, into prostitution. He describes Sonia's silent sacrifice of thirty roubles, her last money, and Katerina Ivanovna's subsequent remorse. Marmeladov recently regained a job but, five days prior, stole his remaining earnings from Katerina Ivanovna's box and has been drunk ever since, using Sonia's money for his current drink. He expresses self-pity and a belief in divine forgiveness.

Marmeladov asks Raskolnikov to escort him home. On the way, he expresses fear of his wife's anger, but more so of the children's hunger. They arrive at a squalid room where Katerina Ivanovna, emaciated and frantic, screams at Marmeladov, searches him for money, and, finding none, drags him by the hair and beats him. The children are terrified. Raskolnikov, disgusted, leaves some coppers on the window-sill and departs, reflecting on Sonia's fate and the "percentage" of people doomed to such lives. He questions his own "hideous" plan, wondering if humanity is inherently good.

The next day, Raskolnikov wakes late, irritable, and starving in his tiny, dirty room. Nastasya, his landlady's servant, brings him tea and soup and informs him that his landlady, Praskovya Pavlovna, plans to report him to the police for unpaid rent. Nastasya then delivers a letter from his mother. The letter details his sister Dounia's past humiliation as a governess in the Svidrigaïlov household, where Mr. Svidrigaïlov made inappropriate advances. Marfa Petrovna, Svidrigaïlov's wife, initially slandered Dounia but later publicly cleared her name after Svidrigaïlov provided proof of Dounia's innocence. Dounia has now accepted a marriage proposal from Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, a wealthy, conceited man who explicitly stated his preference for a poor wife he could control. His mother and Dounia are coming to Petersburg for the wedding, hoping Luzhin will help Raskolnikov's career.

Raskolnikov is enraged by the letter, seeing Dounia's marriage as a sacrifice for his sake. He vows to prevent it, feeling that Marmeladov's question about having "nowhere to turn" resonates with his own desperate situation. His "dream" of committing a crime now seems menacingly real. He wanders aimlessly, then encounters a young, drunk girl on a bench, being preyed upon by a gentleman. Raskolnikov intervenes, giving a policeman twenty copecks to help the girl, but then instantly regrets it, feeling it's not his business. He then recalls he was going to see his friend Razumihin.

He decides not to go to Razumihin's until "after It, when It will be over." He falls asleep in Petrovsky Ostrov and has a nightmare about a peasant brutally beating a thin mare to death. He wakes in terror, realizing the dream's connection to his own plan to kill. He feels he cannot go through with it, but then overhears Lizaveta Ivanovna, the pawnbroker's sister, arranging to be away at seven o'clock the next day. This unexpected information solidifies his resolve, as it means Alyona Ivanovna will be alone.

The next morning, Raskolnikov checks his clothes for bloodstains, finding some on his trousers, which he cuts off. He realizes he still has the stolen purse and trinkets in his pockets and frantically hides them in a hole under the wallpaper. He also removes the axe-carrying loop he had sewn into his coat. He receives a summons to the police office for his debt to the landlady. At the police office, he is irritable but relieved to learn the summons is only for debt. He overhears the superintendent, Nikodim Fomitch, and assistant superintendent, Ilya Petrovitch, discussing the pawnbroker's murder, including the initial suspicion of Koch and Pestryakov, and the later accusation of a painter named Nikolay, who pawned some of the old woman's ear-rings and later tried to hang himself. Raskolnikov faints during this conversation.

Upon recovering, Raskolnikov rushes home, hides the stolen items under a large stone in a deserted courtyard, feeling a momentary triumph. He then goes to Razumihin's, who is surprised by his illness and disheveled appearance. Razumihin offers him translation work and money, but Raskolnikov refuses, wanting to be alone. He walks to the Neva, feels detached, and throws the twenty copecks he received earlier into the water, feeling he has "cut himself off from everyone and from everything."

He returns home and is woken by screams. He hears his landlady being beaten by Ilya Petrovitch on the stairs. Nastasya later tells him he imagined it, attributing it to "the blood crying in his ears." Raskolnikov falls ill with a fever, drifting in and out of consciousness for several days.

When he fully recovers, Razumihin is there, along with a messenger who delivers 35 roubles from his mother. Razumihin explains he has been caring for him, bringing the doctor Zossimov, and even paid off Raskolnikov's IOU to the landlady. Razumihin mentions that during his delirium, Raskolnikov raved about "ear-rings and chains" and his sock. Razumihin has also bought him new clothes.

Zossimov arrives, confirming Raskolnikov's illness is nervous and will pass. Razumihin invites Zossimov to his house-warming, mentioning that Porfiry Petrovitch and Zametov will be there. Razumihin passionately argues against the police's "stupid" investigation of the pawnbroker murder, insisting Nikolay is innocent due to psychological inconsistencies, and that the real murderer must have dropped the ear-rings and hidden.

Luzhin then arrives, dressed ostentatiously. He expresses regret at Raskolnikov's illness and mentions he has found cheap lodgings for Dounia and his mother. He discusses his "modern ideas" of self-interest and then slanders Raskolnikov, accusing him of giving money to Sonia, a "young woman of notorious behaviour." Raskolnikov, enraged, threatens Luzhin and orders him to leave. Luzhin departs, offended. Zossimov and Razumihin discuss Raskolnikov's strange behavior, with Zossimov suspecting a "fixed idea."

Alone again, Raskolnikov feels a strange calm and determination to "end it all to-day." He wanders to the Hay Market, then to a restaurant, where he reads old newspapers about the murder. Zametov, the head clerk, joins him. Raskolnikov, in a fit of nervous bravado, implies his guilt, describing how a clever criminal would hide stolen goods under a stone (exactly what he did). He then directly asks Zametov, "And what if it was I who murdered the old woman and Lizaveta?" Zametov is stunned. Raskolnikov, triumphant, shows Zametov the money and new clothes, suggesting they are from the robbery.

Outside, Razumihin confronts him, furious about his escape from bed. Raskolnikov dismisses him, saying he wants to be alone. He then walks to a bridge, sees a woman drown herself, and feels a profound disgust. Drawn by an "unaccountable prompting," he returns to the old woman's house, finds it being redecorated, and asks the workmen about bloodstains. He reveals his name and address to the porters and workmen, telling them to go to the police station for more information. He then goes to the police office.

At the police office, he finds Ilya Petrovitch. Ilya Petrovitch, in a good mood, talks about Raskolnikov's literary talent. Then, someone mentions that Svidrigaïlov has shot himself. Raskolnikov is shocked. He leaves the office, finds Sonia waiting for him, and tells her he has decided to confess. He complains about the humiliation but accepts a cypress wood cross from her, while she takes Lizaveta's copper cross. He then returns to Ilya Petrovitch and confesses: "It was I killed the old pawnbroker woman and her sister Lizaveta with an axe and robbed them."

**EPILOGUE:**
Raskolnikov is sentenced to eight years of penal servitude in Siberia. During his trial, he confesses all details of the crime, including the hidden items under the stone. The court, struck by his failure to use the money and his lack of memory about the trinkets, concludes the crime was due to "temporary mental derangement." Raskolnikov, however, insists his motive was poverty and a desire to provide for his life, and his confession was due to "heartfelt repentance." Extenuating circumstances, such as his past good deeds (helping a student, saving children from a fire), lead to a merciful sentence.

During the trial, Raskolnikov's mother, Pulcheria Alexandrovna, falls ill with a nervous disorder. Dounia and Razumihin create a false story about Raskolnikov's business trip, but his mother seems to suspect the truth, believing he has powerful enemies and will become a great statesman. Her mental state deteriorates, and she dies of brain fever within a fortnight, having revealed in her delirium that she knew more about his terrible fate.

Two months after Raskolnikov's confession, Dounia marries Razumihin. They plan to move to Siberia in five years to be with Raskolnikov. Sonia, using money from Svidrigaïlov (who had overheard Raskolnikov's confession and provided for Katerina Ivanovna's children before committing suicide), prepares to follow Raskolnikov to Siberia.

In prison, Raskolnikov is not crushed by the physical hardships, but by his wounded pride. He still believes his theory of "extraordinary" men was not stupid, only that he failed. He questions why he didn't kill himself, attributing his survival to instinct. He feels isolated from his fellow prisoners, who despise him for being a "gentleman" and an "infidel." Sonia, however, is loved and respected by all the convicts, who call her "little mother."

Raskolnikov falls ill again and has a dream of a terrible plague that drives people mad and to violence, with only a few chosen to survive. After recovering, he notices he anxiously awaits Sonia's visits. One day, at work on the river bank, Sonia appears. Raskolnikov, overcome, falls at her feet, weeping and embracing her knees. Sonia understands his love, and a light of infinite happiness comes into her eyes. They are both pale and thin, but filled with the "dawn of a new future." They resolve to wait out his seven-year sentence together. Raskolnikov feels a transformation, his crime and imprisonment now seeming "an external, strange fact." He takes Sonia's New Testament, wondering if her convictions can now be his. The story concludes, marking this as the beginning of his gradual renewal and regeneration.
