summary_llm:
Nick Carraway, a young man from the Middle West, moves to West Egg, Long Island, in the spring of 1922 to learn the bond business. He rents a modest house next door to a colossal mansion owned by the mysterious Jay Gatsby. Across the bay, in the more fashionable East Egg, live Nick's second cousin, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy, arrogant husband, Tom Buchanan, a former Yale football star.

Nick visits the Buchanans for dinner and meets Jordan Baker, a professional golfer. During dinner, Tom expresses racist views, and Daisy makes cynical remarks about her daughter, wishing her to be a "beautiful little fool." A phone call interrupts their meal, and Jordan reveals to Nick that Tom has a mistress in New York. Daisy appears tense and later confides in Nick about her unhappiness and cynicism. After dinner, as Nick returns home, he sees Gatsby for the first time, standing on his lawn and stretching his arms toward a distant green light at the end of a dock across the bay.

Some time later, Tom forces Nick to accompany him to the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial area, where Tom introduces Nick to his mistress, Myrtle Wilson. Myrtle is the wife of George Wilson, a spiritless garage owner. Tom arranges to meet Myrtle in New York. In the city, Myrtle changes into an elaborate dress, buys a dog, and hosts a small, raucous party in her apartment. Her sister, Catherine, and the McKees, a couple from downstairs, are present. During the party, Catherine tells Nick a rumor that Gatsby is a relative of Kaiser Wilhelm and that Tom and Myrtle despise their spouses, with Catherine falsely claiming Daisy is Catholic and thus cannot divorce. Myrtle recounts her regretful marriage to George. As the party becomes increasingly drunken, Myrtle provokes Tom by repeatedly shouting Daisy's name, leading Tom to violently break her nose. Nick leaves the chaotic scene.

Throughout the summer, Gatsby hosts lavish parties at his mansion, to which guests often come uninvited. Nick receives a formal invitation and attends one. He feels out of place and struggles to find his host. He reconnects with Jordan Baker, and they hear various rumors about Gatsby's past—that he killed a man, was a German spy, or was in the American army. While searching for Gatsby, they encounter a drunk man with "owl-eyed spectacles" in Gatsby's library, who is astonished that the books are real. Later, Nick meets Gatsby, who recognizes him from the war. Gatsby's smile is described as uniquely reassuring. Gatsby is called away by a phone call from Chicago. Jordan tells Nick that Gatsby claimed to be an "Oxford man" but she doesn't believe it. Gatsby later asks Jordan to convey a "big request" to Nick. As Nick leaves the party, he witnesses a car accident involving the owl-eyed man, who was not driving the car that crashed.

Gatsby invites Nick to lunch. During their drive, Gatsby, aware of the rumors about him, shares his "God's truth": he is the son of wealthy deceased Midwesterners, educated at Oxford, and lived like a "young rajah" in Europe. He shows Nick a war medal from Montenegro and an Oxford photograph as proof. Gatsby then reveals his "big request" will be explained by Jordan. He also demonstrates his influence by getting out of a speeding ticket with a white card. At lunch, Gatsby introduces Nick to Meyer Wolfshiem, a gambler who, Gatsby reveals, fixed the 1919 World's Series. Wolfshiem speaks highly of Gatsby, claiming he "made him" from nothing. Tom Buchanan unexpectedly appears at the restaurant, and Gatsby mysteriously disappears.

Jordan then tells Nick the story of Gatsby and Daisy. Five years prior, in 1917 Louisville, Daisy Fay was a popular young woman who had a romance with Lieutenant Jay Gatsby. Daisy's family prevented her from saying goodbye to Gatsby before he went overseas. She later married Tom Buchanan, who gave her a $350,000 pearl necklace. On the eve of her wedding, Daisy received a letter (presumably from Gatsby), got drunk, and wanted to call off the wedding, but was eventually persuaded to go through with it. After their honeymoon, Tom had a car accident with a chambermaid, breaking her arm, which made the papers. Jordan reveals that Gatsby bought his mansion specifically to be across the bay from Daisy, hoping she would wander into one of his parties. His request is for Nick to invite Daisy to his house for tea so Gatsby can "come over."

Nick agrees to arrange the tea. Gatsby, visibly nervous and pale, prepares his house by having Nick's lawn cut and filling his own mansion with lights. On the day of the tea, it rains heavily. Gatsby, dressed in a white flannel suit, is extremely anxious, almost leaving before Daisy arrives. Daisy arrives, ecstatic, and asks Nick if he's in love with her. Gatsby and Daisy have an awkward reunion, with Gatsby nearly knocking over a clock in his nervousness. Nick leaves them alone for a while. When he returns, Daisy is crying tears of joy, and Gatsby is glowing. Gatsby gives them a tour of his lavish house, including his collection of expensive shirts, which makes Daisy sob, saying she's never seen such beautiful shirts. Gatsby points out the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, realizing its symbolic significance for him has now vanished. Nick sees a photograph of Dan Cody, Gatsby's deceased mentor. Gatsby receives a cryptic phone call. Klipspringer, "the boarder," plays the piano. Nick observes Gatsby, realizing Daisy, in her reality, falls short of Gatsby's idealized dream of her.

Gatsby's parties abruptly cease. He dismisses his gossipy servants and replaces them with people recommended by Wolfshiem, explaining that Daisy now visits frequently in the afternoons. Gatsby calls Nick, asking him to lunch at Daisy's house, and Daisy herself confirms the invitation. During a sweltering lunch at the Buchanans', Daisy openly kisses Gatsby when Tom leaves the room, and murmurs "You know I love you." Daisy's young daughter, Pammy, is brought in, and Gatsby looks at her with surprise, as if he hadn't believed in her existence. Daisy tells Gatsby he "always look so cool," and Tom realizes their affair.

Tom insists they all go to town. Daisy suggests they take Gatsby's car, but Tom insists on driving Gatsby's car, making Nick and Jordan ride with him in his coupé, while Daisy rides with Gatsby. As they drive, Tom reveals he has been investigating Gatsby, dismissing his Oxford claim and accusing him of being a bootlegger. They stop for gas at Wilson's garage. George Wilson is sick and distraught, revealing he has "wised up to something funny" and plans to take Myrtle West, having locked her upstairs. Myrtle is seen peering from a window, her eyes filled with jealous terror, mistakenly fixed on Jordan Baker, whom she believes is Tom's wife.

At the Plaza Hotel, Tom confronts Gatsby, accusing him of having an affair with Daisy and being a "common swindler" who made his money bootlegging alcohol through drugstores. Gatsby counters by saying Daisy never loved Tom and only married him because Gatsby was poor. Daisy, under pressure, admits she loved Tom once, but also loved Gatsby. She then cries, "Oh, you want too much! I love you now—isn’t that enough?" Tom presses her, reminding her of their past. Daisy ultimately cannot bring herself to say she never loved Tom. Gatsby's dream seems to crumble. Tom, with "magnanimous scorn," tells Daisy to go home with Gatsby in Gatsby's car, declaring Gatsby's "presumptuous little flirtation is over." Nick realizes it's his 30th birthday.

As Tom, Nick, and Jordan drive back in Tom's coupé, they pass the valley of ashes. Michaelis, who runs a coffee shop there, recounts the events of the afternoon: George Wilson, having locked Myrtle upstairs, was distraught. Myrtle, after a heated argument with George, rushed out into the road and was struck and killed by a yellow car, which did not stop. Tom, arriving at the accident scene, sees Myrtle's body. He quickly tells Wilson that the yellow car he was driving earlier was not his, and that he had just arrived from New York in a blue coupé, subtly deflecting suspicion from himself and onto Gatsby. Later, Nick sees Tom and Daisy sitting intimately in their kitchen, appearing to conspire.

Nick finds Gatsby waiting outside Daisy's house all night, hoping she will signal him. Gatsby tells Nick that Daisy was driving the yellow car when it hit Myrtle, but he intends to take the blame. He explains Daisy was nervous and wanted to drive, and Myrtle rushed out, seemingly trying to speak to them. Gatsby says Daisy "stepped on it" and he had to pull the emergency brake. Nick leaves Gatsby standing vigil.

The next morning, Nick urges Gatsby to go away, fearing his car will be traced, but Gatsby refuses to leave Daisy. Gatsby reveals more about his past with Daisy: he was a penniless officer who let Daisy believe he was wealthy, taking her under "false pretences." He fell deeply in love, feeling "married to her." While he was at Oxford after the war, Daisy, feeling societal pressure, married Tom. Gatsby describes his desperate return to Louisville, searching for a trace of her.

Gatsby's gardener asks to drain the pool for autumn, but Gatsby, who has never used it all summer, tells him to wait. Nick, feeling a deep connection, tells Gatsby he is "worth the whole damn bunch put together." Later that day, Gatsby puts on his bathing suit and goes to the pool on a pneumatic mattress. George Wilson, having spent the night distraught and searching for the yellow car, eventually makes his way to West Egg, having learned Gatsby's name. The chauffeur hears shots. Nick arrives to find Gatsby's body floating in the pool, and the gardener discovers Wilson's body nearby in the grass.

In the aftermath, police and reporters swarm Gatsby's house. Catherine, Myrtle's sister, lies at the inquest, stating Myrtle never knew Gatsby and was happy with her husband, to avoid scandal. Nick feels responsible for Gatsby, as no one else seems to care. Daisy and Tom have left, taking their luggage and leaving no forwarding address. Nick tries to contact Meyer Wolfshiem, who refuses to get involved, citing "important business." A call comes for Gatsby about a business associate in trouble, further hinting at his illicit dealings.

Gatsby's father, Henry C. Gatz, arrives from Minnesota, a solemn old man who is dismayed but also immensely proud of his son's success. He shows Nick a photograph of Gatsby's house and a childhood book, "Hopalong Cassidy," which contains Gatsby's rigorous schedule for self-improvement. Despite Nick's efforts, almost no one attends Gatsby's funeral except his father, Nick, a minister, a few servants, and the owl-eyed man.

Nick decides to return West, feeling disillusioned with the East. He has a final, strained conversation with Jordan Baker, who reveals she is engaged and accuses Nick of being a "bad driver" himself, dishonest despite his claims of honesty. Nick later encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue. Tom defiantly admits he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, believing Gatsby "had it coming to him" for Myrtle's death. Nick realizes that Tom and Daisy are "careless people" who "smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness... and let other people clean up the mess they had made."

Nick leaves Gatsby's abandoned house, erasing an obscene word scrawled on the steps. He reflects on Gatsby's "incorruptible dream" and his wonder at the green light, realizing that Gatsby's dream of the past was already behind him, and that people are ceaselessly "borne back ceaselessly into the past."

summary_llm:
The provided text, "The Iliad," details a specific period of the Trojan War, focusing primarily on the wrath of Achilles and its consequences, culminating in the death of Hector and the return of his body.

**Book I: The Contention of Achilles and Agamemnon.**
The narrative opens in the tenth year of the siege of Troy. The Greeks have sacked neighboring towns, taking two beautiful captives: Chryseïs, allotted to Agamemnon, and Briseïs, allotted to Achilles. Chryses, a priest of Apollo and father of Chryseïs, arrives at the Greek camp with gifts to ransom his daughter. Agamemnon insolently refuses and dismisses him. Chryses then prays to Apollo for vengeance, and the god inflicts a pestilence upon the Greeks.

Achilles calls a council, where the prophet Chalcas reveals that Apollo's rage is due to Agamemnon's refusal to release Chryseïs. Agamemnon is compelled to return his captive but, in a fit of fury, seizes Briseïs from Achilles as compensation. Enraged and dishonored, Achilles withdraws himself and his Myrmidon forces from the Greek army, vowing not to fight.

Achilles complains to his mother, Thetis, a sea goddess. She ascends to Olympus and supplicates Jupiter (Jove) to grant victory to the Trojans, thereby making the Greeks realize the severe wrong done to her son. Jupiter grants her request, which incenses Juno, his wife and sister. A heated debate ensues between Jupiter and Juno, eventually pacified by their son, Vulcan.

The events of this book span twenty-two days: nine days for the plague, one for the council and quarrel, and twelve days during Jupiter's absence with the Æthiopians before Thetis presents her petition.

**Book II: The Trial of the Army, and Catalogue of the Forces.**
To fulfill Thetis's request, Jupiter sends a deceitful dream to Agamemnon, disguised as the wise Nestor. The dream urges Agamemnon to lead the Greeks into battle, promising him that Troy will fall immediately. Agamemnon, deluded by this vision, decides to test the army's morale. He proposes to the Greek princes that they should return home, expecting them to object and rally the troops.

When Agamemnon presents this proposal to the assembled army, the soldiers, weary from nine years of war and the recent plague, unanimously agree to abandon the siege and rush to prepare their ships for departure. Juno, observing this, sends Pallas (Minerva) to Ulysses, urging him to stop the flight. Ulysses, taking Agamemnon's royal scepter, moves through the ranks, persuading the leaders and chastising the common soldiers. He silences Thersites, a loud and insolent commoner who publicly criticizes Agamemnon, by striking him with the scepter.

The assembly is recalled. Nestor advises Agamemnon to organize the troops by their nations and tribes before battle. Agamemnon agrees, and the Greek forces are marshaled. The narrative then provides a detailed "Catalogue of Ships," listing the various Greek contingents, their leaders, and their origins (e.g., Boeotia, Athens, Sparta, Crete, Pylos). Notably, Achilles' Myrmidons are present but remain inactive due to their leader's wrath.

Meanwhile, Iris, sent by Jupiter, warns the Trojan chiefs (disguised as Priam's son, Polites) of the approaching Greek army. Hector, the Trojan leader, immediately gathers all Trojan and allied forces, including Dardans, Lycians, Paeonians, and others. Both armies prepare for battle on the plain before Troy.

**Book III: The Duel of Menelaus and Paris.**
The Greek and Trojan armies advance, the Trojans with shouts, the Greeks in silence. Paris, the cause of the war, steps forward from the Trojan ranks and challenges any Greek to single combat. Menelaus, the Spartan king whose wife Helen was abducted by Paris, joyfully accepts. Paris, however, shrinks back in fear at the sight of Menelaus. Hector rebukes Paris for his cowardice.

Paris, shamed, then proposes a single combat between himself and Menelaus to decide the war, with Helen and all the treasures she brought to Troy as the prize. Hector conveys this challenge to the Greeks, and Menelaus accepts. A solemn truce is agreed upon, and Priam, the aged king of Troy, comes to the battlefield to swear the oaths for the Trojans, accompanied by Agamemnon for the Greeks.

Iris, disguised as Laodice, goes to Helen in the palace and urges her to come to the Scaean Gate to witness the duel. Helen, filled with longing for her former life, joins Priam and the Trojan elders on the walls. From there, she identifies prominent Greek leaders for Priam, including Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Ajax.

The duel begins. Paris throws his spear first, but it is deflected by Menelaus's shield. Menelaus throws his spear, which pierces Paris's shield and corslet, but Paris narrowly avoids a fatal wound. Menelaus then attacks with his sword, which shatters on Paris's helmet. Menelaus seizes Paris by his helmet-crest and begins to drag him towards the Greek lines. At this critical moment, Venus, Paris's divine protector, intervenes. She breaks the helmet strap, frees Paris, and, shrouding him in a cloud, transports him safely back to his perfumed chamber in Troy.

Venus then, disguised as an old woman, compels a reluctant Helen to join Paris in his chamber. Helen initially scorns Paris for his cowardice but eventually succumbs to Venus's pressure and embraces him. Back on the battlefield, Agamemnon declares Menelaus the victor and demands the immediate return of Helen and the treasures, along with the agreed-upon fine. The Greek army loudly applauds his demand.

**Book IV: The Breach of the Truce, and the First Battle.**
The gods convene on Olympus to discuss the war. Jupiter, seeing the truce broken, suggests ending the conflict peacefully by allowing Menelaus to reclaim Helen. This suggestion enrages Juno, who insists on the utter destruction of Troy. Jupiter, though annoyed by her persistent hatred, eventually yields to her will, warning her that he may one day destroy her favored cities in return. He then sends Minerva (Pallas) to break the truce definitively and reignite the battle.

Minerva descends to the battlefield, disguised as Laodocus, a Trojan warrior. She approaches Pandarus, a skilled Trojan archer, and persuades him to shoot an arrow at Menelaus, promising him glory and rich rewards from Paris. Pandarus, swayed by the goddess, shoots an arrow that wounds Menelaus. The wound is not fatal, as Minerva subtly deflects the arrow from a vital spot, but it is enough to break the truce.

Agamemnon is deeply distressed by Menelaus's wound and the treachery of the Trojans. He expresses his fear that the Greeks will abandon the war if Menelaus dies. Machaon, the Greek physician, is summoned and successfully extracts the arrow and heals Menelaus.

Agamemnon then moves through the Greek ranks, rallying his troops. He praises valiant leaders like Idomeneus and the Ajaces, and sternly reproves those who seem hesitant, such as Ulysses and Diomed, reminding them of their duty and past glories. Inspired by their king, the Greeks prepare for battle.

The armies clash fiercely. Antilochus kills Echepolus. Ajax kills Simoisius. Ulysses kills Democoon. Apollo, seeing the Trojans falter, encourages them. The battle becomes a bloody melee, with many heroes falling on both sides. Pyrus kills Diores, and Thoas kills Pyrus. The field is covered with dead and wounded, and the conflict rages with immense fury.

**Book V: The Acts of Diomed.**
Pallas (Minerva) inspires Diomed with extraordinary strength and courage, making him shine with a divine light, intending to raise his fame above all other Greeks. Diomed immediately enters the fray, killing Phegeus and Idæus, sons of Dares. Pallas then restrains Mars, the god of war, and instructs Diomed that he can distinguish gods from mortals and is permitted to wound Venus if she enters the battle, but must avoid all other deities.

Diomed continues his rampage, killing Odius, Phaestus, Scamandrius, Phereclus, Pedaeus, and Hypsenor. Pandarus wounds Diomed with an arrow, but Pallas heals him and reinforces her earlier instructions. Æneas, seeing Pandarus's success, joins him in a chariot to confront Diomed. Diomed kills Pandarus with his spear, then throws a massive stone that shatters Æneas's hip.

Venus, Æneas's mother, rushes to her son's aid, covering him with her veil to protect him. Diomed, remembering Pallas's instruction, pursues Venus and wounds her hand with his spear. Venus, shrieking, drops Æneas and flees to Olympus with the help of Iris, complaining to Dione and Jupiter about being wounded by a mortal. Jupiter gently rebukes her, telling her to leave war to Mars and Pallas and focus on love.

Apollo rescues Æneas, taking him to his temple in Troy where Latona and Phoebe heal him. Apollo then creates a phantom of Æneas to maintain the Trojan morale and urges Mars to re-enter the battle and rally the Trojans. Sarpedon, a Lycian ally, also rebukes Hector for his perceived inaction, spurring him to fight. Hector, shamed, rallies his troops.

The real Æneas, fully healed, returns to the battle. Tlepolemus, son of Hercules, challenges Sarpedon, son of Jupiter. They exchange spears; Sarpedon kills Tlepolemus but is wounded in the thigh. Jupiter, though saddened, allows fate to take its course. Ulysses, enraged by Tlepolemus's death, slaughters many Lycians.

Hector and Mars drive the Greeks back. Diomed, seeing Mars, advises a tactical retreat. Ajax makes a fierce stand, killing several Trojans, but is eventually forced to give ground under a shower of darts. Juno and Minerva prepare to intervene again, but Jupiter sends Iris to warn them against defying his will, threatening severe punishment. They reluctantly return to Olympus.

Minerva, however, later inspires Diomed to attack Mars directly. Diomed, guided by Pallas, wounds Mars in the groin with his spear. Mars bellows in pain and flees to Olympus, where Jupiter rebukes him for his constant warring. Paeon heals Mars. Juno and Pallas, having completed their task, return to the other gods.

**Book VI: The Episodes of Glaucus and Diomed, and of Hector and Andromache.**
With the gods having withdrawn from direct combat, the Greeks gain the upper hand. Ajax kills Acamas. Diomed kills Axylus and his servant Calesius. Euryalus kills Dresus, Opheltius, and two sons of Bucolion. Other Greek heroes also achieve kills, including Polypoetes, Ulysses, Teucer, Nestor's son, Agamemnon, Eurypylus, and Leitus.

Menelaus captures Adrastus, who begs for his life and offers ransom. Menelaus is inclined to spare him, but Agamemnon intervenes, urging merciless slaughter, and kills Adrastus himself. Nestor then encourages the Greeks to continue fighting and not to stop for plunder until the enemy is routed.

Helenus, the chief augur of Troy, advises Hector to return to the city. He instructs Hector to tell his mother, Hecuba, to lead the Trojan matrons in a solemn procession to Minerva's temple, offering a precious mantle and twelve heifers, to entreat the goddess to remove Diomed from the fight. Hector agrees, rallies his troops, and departs for Troy.

Meanwhile, Glaucus, a Lycian ally, and Diomed meet between the armies. Diomed asks Glaucus's lineage, stating he avoids fighting gods. Glaucus recounts his ancestry, tracing it to Bellerophon, a hero who overcame many challenges. Recognizing that their grandfathers, Oeneus and Bellerophon, were guest-friends, Diomed and Glaucus agree not to fight each other. As a token of their renewed ancestral friendship, they exchange armor, with Glaucus foolishly trading his golden armor for Diomed's bronze.

Hector arrives in Troy and is greeted by his mother, Hecuba, who offers him wine. He refuses, deeming himself too stained with blood for sacred rites. He then conveys Helenus's instructions to Hecuba, who leads the Trojan women in their procession and prayers to Minerva, but their prayers are in vain.

Hector then goes to Paris's house, finding him polishing his armor. Hector sternly rebukes Paris for his idleness while Troy suffers. Paris, acknowledging his fault, agrees to return to battle. Helen also expresses her self-blame and sorrow.

Before returning to the field, Hector seeks his wife, Andromache, and their infant son, Astyanax, at the Scaean Gate. Andromache tearfully pleads with him to stay within the city walls, fearing for his life and the future of their son and Troy. Hector explains his duty to fight for his country and his honor, foreseeing Troy's eventual fall and Andromache's enslavement. He prays to Jupiter that Astyanax may become a great warrior. After a tender farewell, Hector and Paris rejoin the battle.

**Book VII: The Single Combat of Hector and Ajax.**
With Hector and Paris back in the field, the battle renews with increased ferocity. Paris kills Menestheus, Hector kills Eioneus, and Glaucus kills Iphinous. Minerva, concerned for the Greeks, descends from Olympus and meets Apollo near the Scaean Gate. They agree to halt the general engagement for the day and inspire Hector to challenge a Greek to single combat.

Helenus, the Trojan seer, divining the gods' will, advises Hector to issue this challenge. Hector steps forward and proposes a duel, stating that the victor will take the loser's armor, but the body must be returned for proper burial. The Greeks are initially silent, fearing Hector's might. Menelaus, enraged, volunteers, but Agamemnon restrains him, reminding him of Hector's superior strength.

Nestor then shames the Greeks for their hesitation, recounting his own youthful valor. Nine Greek chiefs, including Agamemnon, Diomed, Ajax Telamon, Oileus, Idomeneus, Meriones, Eurypylus, Thoas, and Ulysses, step forward to accept the challenge. Lots are cast, and Ajax Telamon is chosen.

Ajax arms himself in his formidable sevenfold shield and advances. Hector and Ajax exchange boasts. Hector throws his spear, which strikes Ajax's shield but does not pierce it. Ajax then throws his spear, piercing Hector's shield and corslet, grazing his flank. They then engage with swords. Hector throws a stone at Ajax's shield. Ajax retaliates with a larger stone, knocking Hector to the ground. Apollo quickly restores Hector's strength. As they prepare to resume fighting with swords, heralds from both sides, Idæus for Troy and Talthybius for Greece, intervene to stop the combat due to nightfall, declaring it a draw by divine will.

As a sign of mutual respect, Hector and Ajax exchange gifts: Hector gives Ajax a sword, and Ajax gives Hector a purple belt. Both heroes then return to their respective armies. The Trojans joyfully welcome Hector back to the city. The Greeks celebrate Ajax's prowess.

Agamemnon hosts a feast for the Greek chiefs. Nestor advises them to use the truce to burn their dead and to build a defensive wall, trench, and palisades around their camp and ships. Priam calls a council in Troy. Antenor proposes returning Helen and the treasures to end the war, but Paris refuses to return Helen, though he offers to return the treasures and add his own wealth. Priam then sends Idæus to the Greeks with Paris's offer and a request for a truce to bury the dead. Diomed rejects the offer of wealth but Agamemnon agrees to the truce for burial.

Both armies spend the next day performing funeral rites for their fallen comrades. The Greeks then build their fortifications. Neptune, seeing the wall being built without offerings to the gods, complains to Jupiter, fearing it will diminish the glory of the walls he and Apollo built for Laomedon. Jupiter assures Neptune that he will eventually destroy the Greek wall. That night, both armies feast, but Jupiter sends thunder and lightning to signify his displeasure with the Trojans.

**Book VIII: The Second Battle, and the Distress of the Greeks.**
At dawn, Jupiter convenes a council of the gods on Olympus. He sternly forbids any deity from intervening in the battle, threatening severe punishment (including being cast into Tartarus) for disobedience. Minerva is only permitted to offer counsel to the Greeks, not direct aid. Jupiter then takes his chariot to Mount Ida to oversee the battle from afar.

The armies clash. Jupiter weighs the fates of Greece and Troy in his golden scales; the Greek scale sinks. He then sends thunder and lightning to terrify the Greeks, causing them to retreat. Nestor's horse is wounded by Paris's arrow, putting the aged king in danger from Hector. Diomed rescues Nestor, but Ulysses flees to the ships. Diomed and Nestor confront Hector, but Jupiter sends another lightning bolt, forcing them to retreat. Hector boasts of his impending victory and his plan to burn the Greek ships.

Juno, distressed by the Greek losses, complains to Neptune, urging him to intervene, but Neptune refuses to defy Jupiter. Agamemnon, inspired by Juno, rallies the Greeks and prays to Jupiter for aid. Jupiter sends an eagle carrying a fawn as an omen, which encourages the Greeks.

Diomed leads a renewed charge, killing Agelaus. The Atridae, Ajaces, Meriones, Idomeneus, and Teucer follow. Teucer, protected by Ajax's shield, kills several Trojans with his arrows. However, when Teucer aims at Hector, Apollo deflects the arrow, and Hector retaliates by throwing a stone that breaks Teucer's bowstring, disabling him. Ajax and Mecistheus carry Teucer from the field.

The Trojans, emboldened by Jupiter's favor, drive the Greeks back towards their fortifications. Hector leads the charge. Juno and Minerva again prepare to intervene, but Iris, sent by Jupiter, warns them of Jupiter's wrath and threats of punishment. They reluctantly return to Olympus. Jupiter then confirms his prophecy to Juno: Hector will continue to triumph until Achilles returns to battle after Patroclus's death, at which point Hector will die and Troy will fall.

As night falls, the Trojans have driven the Greeks back to their ships. Hector calls a council and decides to camp on the plain outside the city, lighting numerous fires to prevent the Greeks from escaping by sea during the night. He plans a decisive assault on the ships at dawn. The Trojans feast and maintain watch throughout the night.

**Book IX: The Embassy to Achilles.**
The Greeks are in deep despair after the day's defeat, with the Trojan fires burning brightly near their ships. Agamemnon, overwhelmed, proposes abandoning the siege and returning to Greece. Diomed vehemently opposes this, declaring he will stay and fight even if all others leave. Nestor praises Diomed's courage and advises Agamemnon to strengthen the guards and call a council of elders. He then suggests sending an embassy to Achilles to appease his wrath with gifts and persuade him to return to battle.

Agamemnon agrees and offers an immense array of gifts to Achilles: ten talents of gold, twenty shining vases, seven sacred tripods, twelve swift horses, seven beautiful Lesbian captives (including Briseïs, whom he swears he never touched), and promises of more wealth if Troy falls, twenty Trojan women, one of his three daughters in marriage without a dowry, and the rule over seven rich cities.

Nestor selects Phoenix (Achilles' aged tutor), the mighty Ajax Telamon, and the wise Ulysses as ambassadors, accompanied by two heralds. They travel through the night to Achilles' tent, praying to Neptune. They find Achilles playing the lyre, with Patroclus listening. Achilles welcomes them as friends and offers them a feast.

Ulysses presents Agamemnon's offer, detailing the desperate situation of the Greeks and reminding Achilles of his father Peleus's advice to control his anger and be humane. Achilles, however, firmly rejects the offer. He reiterates his deep resentment towards Agamemnon for the dishonor and states that he values his life over glory. He announces his intention to sail home on the third day. He scorns Agamemnon's gifts and refuses his daughter in marriage. He invites Phoenix to stay with him, respecting his age.

Phoenix then tearfully recounts his own history as Achilles' tutor and appeals to Achilles' compassion, telling the story of Meleager, who refused to fight until his city was on the verge of destruction, only to receive no reward for his eventual intervention. Achilles acknowledges Phoenix as a second father but remains steadfast in his refusal to fight for Agamemnon.

Ajax then speaks, rebuking Achilles for his stubbornness and lack of pity for his suffering countrymen, emphasizing the common cause and the immense atonement offered. Achilles respects Ajax's words but maintains his anger against Agamemnon. He declares he will not return to battle until Hector reaches his own ships and sets them on fire.

The ambassadors return to Agamemnon's tent, leaving Phoenix with Achilles. Ulysses reports Achilles' unyielding refusal and his plan to depart. Diomed responds by asserting that they should not rely on Achilles but prepare to fight bravely at dawn. The Greeks make libations and then go to sleep.

**Book X: The Night-Adventure of Diomed and Ulysses.**
Agamemnon, unable to sleep due to anxiety, rises and goes to Nestor's tent, finding the old king also awake and armed. They discuss the dire situation of the Greek army. Nestor suggests waking other key leaders. Agamemnon goes to Menelaus, who is also awake with concern. Menelaus then goes to wake Ajax and Idomeneus. Nestor wakes Ulysses and Diomed.

The chiefs gather in a council of war near the night guards. Nestor proposes sending a spy into the Trojan camp to gather intelligence on their plans and dispositions. Diomed volunteers for this hazardous mission and chooses Ulysses as his companion. They arm themselves: Diomed with a shield and a simple helmet, Ulysses with a sword, bow, quiver, and a boar's-tusk helmet. Minerva sends a heron as a favorable omen, and they pray to Pallas for success.

Meanwhile, Hector also calls for a volunteer to spy on the Greek camp, offering Achilles' chariot and immortal horses as a reward. Dolon, a swift but not handsome Trojan youth, volunteers, explicitly asking for Achilles' horses. Hector swears an oath to grant them. Dolon disguises himself with a wolf's hide and a ferret's fur helmet and sets out.

Diomed and Ulysses spot Dolon. They let him pass a short distance, then pursue and capture him. Dolon, terrified, begs for his life and, under interrogation, reveals the Trojan dispositions: Hector and the Trojan peers are holding a council at Ilus' monument, the native Trojans are keeping watch by their fires, but the auxiliary forces (Paeonians, Carians, Caucons, Pelasgians, Leleges, Lycians, Mysians, Maeonians, Phrygians, Thracians) are sleeping without strict guard. He specifically mentions Rhesus, the Thracian king, who recently arrived with magnificent, white horses.

Diomed, despite Dolon's pleas, kills him with his sword, stating that a traitor should not be allowed to escape. Ulysses dedicates Dolon's spoils to Pallas and marks the spot. They then proceed to the Thracian camp. Diomed slaughters Rhesus and twelve other Thracian warriors in their sleep. Ulysses unties Rhesus's famous white horses. Pallas appears and warns them that Apollo is about to rouse the Trojans, urging them to return. They ride Rhesus's horses back to the Greek camp.

Nestor, hearing the approaching horses, is the first to recognize their return. Diomed and Ulysses are greeted triumphantly by the other chiefs and recount their successful raid. Rhesus's horses are taken to Diomed's stalls, and Dolon's armor is dedicated to Pallas. The heroes cleanse themselves and feast, pouring libations to Pallas.

**Book XI: The Third Battle, and the Acts of Agamemnon.**
As dawn breaks, Eris (Discord), sent by Jupiter, descends to the Greek fleet, inspiring the warriors with fierce resolve. Agamemnon arms himself in splendid, divinely crafted armor and leads the Greeks into battle. Juno and Minerva support the Greeks with thunder. Jupiter sends down drops of blood, foreshadowing the day's slaughter.

The Trojans, led by Hector, Polydamas, Æneas, and others, array themselves near Ilus' tomb. Hector, shining in his armor, moves through the ranks. The battle begins with intense fighting on both sides, neither yielding. Agamemnon leads the charge, killing Bienor and his squire Oïleus. He then kills two sons of Priam, Isus and Antiphus, and two sons of Antimachus, Pisander and Hippolochus, refusing their pleas for ransom. Agamemnon's fury drives the Trojans back towards the city walls.

Jupiter, seeing Agamemnon's success, sends Iris to Hector. Iris delivers Jupiter's command: Hector must withdraw from the front while Agamemnon rages, but when Agamemnon is wounded and retreats, Hector will be granted strength and victory until sunset. Hector obeys, withdrawing his main force.

Coön, Antenor's eldest son, wounds Agamemnon in the arm. Agamemnon kills Coön but is overcome by agonizing pain from his wound. He mounts his chariot and retreats to the ships. Hector, seeing Agamemnon's withdrawal, charges the Greeks with renewed fury, killing many heroes.

Ulysses and Diomed make a stand, rallying the Greeks. Diomed kills Thymbraeus and Molion. Hector confronts Diomed, who throws a spear that grazes Hector's helmet. Hector is stunned but recovers. Paris then shoots an arrow from a distance, piercing Diomed's foot. Paris boasts, but Diomed insults him as a cowardly archer and is carried to his chariot by Ulysses.

Ulysses is left alone and surrounded by Trojans. He fights bravely, killing several enemies, but is eventually wounded by Socus. Ulysses calls for aid, and Menelaus and Ajax rush to his rescue, driving off the Trojans and carrying Ulysses to his chariot. Ajax continues to fight fiercely, killing Doryclus, Pandocus, and Lysander.

Hector continues his rampage on the left wing. Paris wounds Machaon, the physician, with an arrow in the shoulder. Idomeneus urges Nestor to take Machaon to the ships, as a physician is invaluable. Nestor does so.

Hector, seeing the Greek distress, drives them back to their ships. Ajax, overwhelmed by the Trojan assault, is forced to retreat. Eurypylus is wounded by Paris while defending the Greeks. Achilles, observing the battle from his ship, sees Nestor's chariot carrying a wounded man and sends Patroclus to inquire who it is.

Patroclus goes to Nestor's tent. Nestor recounts the day's heavy losses, with many chiefs wounded, and laments Achilles' inaction. He then tells a long story of his own youthful valor and reminds Patroclus of the advice given to him and Achilles by their fathers. Nestor urges Patroclus to persuade Achilles to fight, or at least to lead the Myrmidons into battle clad in Achilles' armor, to frighten the Trojans and save the fleet. On his way back, Patroclus encounters the wounded Eurypylus, takes him to his tent, removes the arrow, and applies healing balms.

**Book XII: The Battle at the Grecian Wall.**
While Patroclus tends to Eurypylus, the battle rages at the Greek fortifications. The narrator foretells that the Greek wall, built without divine offerings, will eventually be destroyed by Neptune and Apollo after Troy's fall.

Hector leads the Trojans to the Greek trench, but their chariots cannot cross the deep, spiked ditch. Polydamas advises Hector to dismount and attack the wall on foot, dividing the army into five battalions. Hector agrees. The Trojans dismount and form their battalions, with Hector, Polydamas, and Cebriones leading the first.

Asius, however, disobeys Polydamas's counsel and attempts to drive his chariot through one of the gates, but he is repelled by two Lapith chiefs, Polypoetes and Leonteus, who bravely defend the entrance. Asius complains about the unexpected Greek resistance.

An ominous sign appears: an eagle carrying a bleeding serpent drops it among the Trojans. Polydamas interprets this as a warning that they will breach the wall but fail to take the ships, suffering heavy losses. He advises retreat. Hector furiously rejects this, asserting his trust in Jupiter's previous signs of victory and threatening Polydamas for his cowardice.

Hector then leads a fierce assault on the wall, aided by a whirlwind from Jupiter. The Trojans undermine the wall and tear down the piles supporting it. Sarpedon, Jupiter's son and a Lycian leader, delivers a stirring speech to Glaucus, urging them to fight for glory. Sarpedon then attacks the wall and, with Glaucus, makes the first breach. Ajax kills Epicles, a friend of Sarpedon, with a stone. Teucer wounds Glaucus with an arrow, forcing him to retreat. Sarpedon, despite Glaucus's injury, continues to fight, killing Alcmaon and widening the breach.

Finally, Hector, empowered by Jupiter, lifts a massive stone and smashes it through one of the main gates, breaking the bars. He then rushes through the breach, shining like a god, and leads the Trojans pouring into the Greek camp. The Greeks, terrified, flee towards their ships.

**Book XIII: The Fourth Battle Continued, in which Neptune Assists the Greeks: The Acts of Idomeneus.**
Jupiter, having seen Hector breach the Greek wall, turns his attention away from the battle, leaving the outcome to fate. Neptune, the god of the sea, observes the Greek distress from Samothracia. Incensed at Jupiter's partiality, he emerges from the deep and, disguised as the seer Calchas, inspires the Ajaces to resist Hector. He then encourages other retreating Greeks, instilling new courage in them.

The Ajaces form a strong phalanx, halting Hector's advance. Meriones, having broken his spear, goes to Idomeneus's tent for a new one. Idomeneus, the Cretan king, also eager to fight, arms himself and returns to battle with Meriones. Idomeneus displays great valor, killing Othryoneus, Asius (who had tried to force the gate in his chariot), and Alcathous.

Deiphobus, enraged by Alcathous's death, confronts Idomeneus and calls Æneas to his aid. Æneas, who had been sulking due to Priam's perceived slights, joins the fight. A fierce battle erupts around Alcathous's body. Idomeneus kills Oenomaus. Deiphobus wounds Ascalaphus, son of Mars. Meriones wounds Deiphobus, who is then carried off by Polites. Æneas kills Aphareus, and Antilochus kills Thoon. Meriones wounds Adamas, son of Asius. Helenus wounds Deipyrus.

Menelaus wounds Helenus with an arrow and then kills Pisander, who attacked him. Meriones kills Harpalion. Paris kills Euchenor. Hector remains at the central breach, fighting against various Greek contingents. The Locrian archers, fighting from the rear, rain arrows and stones upon the Trojans.

Polydamas, seeing the heavy losses and the continued danger, again advises Hector to call a council and consider retreating, fearing Achilles' eventual return. Hector agrees to the council but first goes to rally the Trojans, rebuking Paris for his absence. Hector returns to the central battle and confronts Ajax. They exchange boasts, and the battle continues fiercely as night approaches.

**Book XIV: Juno Deceives Jupiter by the Girdle of Venus.**
Nestor, sitting with the wounded Machaon, hears the intensifying sounds of battle and, leaving Machaon to be cared for, goes to investigate. He encounters Agamemnon, Diomed, and Ulysses, all wounded and retreating from the front lines. Agamemnon, in despair, proposes abandoning the siege and fleeing by night. Ulysses vehemently rebukes him for his cowardly suggestion, reminding him of their duty and the shame it would bring. Diomed advises the wounded chiefs to return to the front to encourage the troops with their presence, but to remain out of direct combat. They agree and proceed to the battle lines. Neptune, disguised as an old warrior, encourages Agamemnon, promising victory.

Meanwhile, Juno, observing Jupiter on Mount Ida aiding the Trojans, devises a plan to distract him. She meticulously adorns herself with ambrosial oils, a radiant mantle, and dazzling jewelry. She then goes to Venus and, under the false pretense of wanting to reconcile Ocean and Tethys, obtains Venus's magic girdle, which contains all charms of love, desire, and persuasion.

Next, Juno seeks out Sleep. Sleep is initially reluctant, recalling a past instance where Jupiter punished him for putting him to sleep to aid Hercules. Juno promises him Pasithaë, one of the Graces, as his wife, and swears a solemn oath by the river Styx and the Titans to ensure her promise. Sleep agrees and hides in a fir tree on Mount Ida, disguised as a bird.

Juno then approaches Jupiter on Ida. Jupiter is immediately captivated by her beauty and, despite her feigned reluctance, embraces her. Golden clouds envelop them, concealing them from view. Overcome by love and the influence of Sleep, Jupiter falls into a deep slumber.

Sleep immediately informs Neptune that Jupiter is asleep. Neptune, emboldened, rushes to aid the Greeks, rallying them and urging them to fight fiercely. Hector throws his spear at Ajax, but it is deflected. Ajax then hurls a massive stone, striking Hector in the chest and knocking him unconscious. Polydamas, Agenor, and Æneas carry the unconscious Hector from the field to the Xanthus river, where he slowly regains consciousness. With Hector removed, the Greeks press their advantage, and the battle turns in their favor. Ajax the Lesser particularly distinguishes himself in the ensuing slaughter.

**Book XV: The Fifth Battle at the Ships; and the Acts of Ajax.**
Jupiter awakens on Mount Ida and immediately perceives the deception: the Trojans are fleeing, Hector is wounded, and Neptune is aiding the Greeks. Enraged, he confronts Juno, reminding her of past punishments for her interference and threatening her with further wrath. Juno, trembling, denies her involvement, blaming Neptune's independent will and swearing by Styx and the Titans.

Jupiter accepts her oath and commands her to send Iris and Apollo to him. Iris is to order Neptune to withdraw from the battle, and Apollo is to restore Hector's strength and lead the Trojans back to the fight. Jupiter then reiterates his prophecy: Hector will drive the Greeks to their ships, Patroclus will fight in Achilles' armor, Patroclus will kill Sarpedon, Hector will kill Patroclus, and then Achilles will kill Hector, leading to Troy's eventual fall.

Juno flies to Olympus and informs the other gods of Jupiter's threats. Mars, enraged by the death of his son Ascalaphus, prepares to defy Jupiter, but Minerva restrains him. Iris and Apollo then go to Jupiter on Ida. Iris delivers Jupiter's command to Neptune, ordering him to withdraw from the battle. Neptune initially expresses defiance, asserting his equal birthright as a son of Saturn, but eventually yields, though resentfully, and plunges into the sea.

Apollo goes to Hector, heals him, and fills him with renewed strength. Hector, restored and invigorated, returns to battle, inspiring the Trojans and terrifying the Greeks. Apollo leads the Trojans, carrying Jupiter's aegis, which strikes terror into the Greeks and turns the tide of battle once more. Apollo then pushes down a large section of the Greek wall and fills the trench, creating a clear path for the Trojans to reach the ships.

The Trojans rush towards the Greek ships, intending to burn them. Patroclus, still tending to Eurypylus, sees the ships in danger and rushes back to Achilles to urge him to fight. Hector attacks the ship of Protesilaus. Clytius attempts to set it on fire but is killed by Ajax. Ajax fiercely defends the ships, killing Lycophron. Teucer joins him, but when he aims at Hector, Jupiter breaks his bowstring. Ajax tells Teucer to use a spear instead. Hector boasts of Jupiter's favor and urges the Trojans to burn the ships. Ajax rallies the Greeks, reminding them that their only hope is to fight or die defending the ships. The battle rages intensely around the ships, with Hector seizing one vessel. Ajax, overwhelmed by the continuous assault, is forced to retreat, though he kills twelve Trojans who try to set the ships on fire.

**Book XVI: The Sixth Battle, the Acts and Death of Patroclus.**
As the battle rages and the Greek ships begin to burn, Patroclus, weeping, approaches Achilles' tent. He pleads with Achilles to return to battle or, at least, to allow him to lead the Myrmidons into battle clad in Achilles' armor, to frighten the Trojans and save the fleet.

Achilles, moved by Patroclus's tears and the sight of the burning ships, agrees to his request. However, he gives Patroclus strict instructions: he must only repel the Trojans from the ships and not pursue them to Troy's walls, lest a god intervene and cause his death. Achilles expresses a wish that all Greeks and Trojans might die, leaving only himself and Patroclus to sack Troy.

Patroclus arms himself in Achilles' splendid armor (except for Achilles' spear, which only Achilles can wield). Automedon harnesses Achilles' immortal horses, Xanthus and Balius, along with the mortal Pedasus. Achilles then offers a libation to Jupiter, praying for Patroclus's success and safe return. Jupiter grants the first part of the prayer (success in repelling the Trojans) but denies the latter (Patroclus's safe return).

Patroclus leads the Myrmidons into battle. The Trojans, seeing Achilles' armor, are struck with panic, believing Achilles has returned. Patroclus kills Pyrechmes and drives the Trojans from the ships, extinguishing the fires. He then goes on a rampage, killing numerous Trojan heroes, including Areilycus, Thoas, Amphidus, Atymnius, Maris, Cleobulus, Lycon, Neamas, and Erymas. Hector is forced to retreat, and the Trojans are driven back towards the trench.

Sarpedon, Jupiter's son and a Lycian leader, rallies his forces and confronts Patroclus. Jupiter debates whether to save his son but is persuaded by Juno to let fate take its course. Jupiter weeps tears of blood, and Patroclus kills Sarpedon with a spear to the chest. A fierce battle erupts over Sarpedon's body. Glaucus, though wounded, prays to Apollo for strength, which is granted, and he rallies the Lycians and Trojans. Hector joins the fight for Sarpedon's body. The Greeks eventually manage to strip Sarpedon's armor. Jupiter commands Apollo to take Sarpedon's body, cleanse it, anoint it, and send it to Lycia via Sleep and Death for proper burial.

Patroclus, ignoring Achilles' strict command, pursues the fleeing Trojans to the walls of Troy. He attempts to scale the walls three times but is repelled by Apollo. Apollo, disguised as Asius, warns Hector to attack Patroclus, promising divine aid. Hector drives his chariot towards Patroclus. Patroclus throws a stone, killing Cebriones, Hector's charioteer. A battle ensues over Cebriones' body.

Apollo, shrouded in a cloud, strikes Patroclus from behind, disarming him by breaking his spear, shield strap, and helmet. Euphorbus, a Dardan youth, then wounds Patroclus with a spear but retreats. Hector then delivers the fatal blow with his spear. As he dies, Patroclus prophesies Hector's imminent death by Achilles' hand. Hector boasts over Patroclus's body and strips Achilles' armor from him. Automedon drives Achilles' horses away from the battle.

**Book XVII: The Seventh Battle, for the Body of Patroclus.—The Acts of Menelaus.**
Upon Patroclus's death, Menelaus immediately rushes to defend his body from the Trojans. Euphorbus, who had wounded Patroclus, challenges Menelaus and is killed by him. Menelaus begins to strip Euphorbus's armor. Apollo, disguised as Mentes, warns Hector that Menelaus has killed Euphorbus and is about to strip Patroclus's body of Achilles' armor.

Hector, hearing this, rushes back to the scene. Menelaus, seeing Hector approaching in Achilles' armor (which Hector had already taken from Patroclus), reluctantly retreats. Hector then seizes Patroclus's body, intending to drag it away. Menelaus calls for Ajax Telamon, who quickly arrives. Together, Ajax and Menelaus stand over Patroclus's body, defending it.

Glaucus, the Lycian leader, rebukes Hector for abandoning Sarpedon's body and for his perceived cowardice against Ajax. He urges Hector to fight fiercely for Patroclus's body, suggesting it could be exchanged for Sarpedon's. Stung by the rebuke, Hector puts on Achilles' armor (which he had taken from Patroclus) and rallies his troops, promising rich rewards to anyone who can drag Patroclus's body to Troy.

Jupiter, seeing Hector in Achilles' divine armor, pities him and grants him a moment of glory before his fated death. A fierce battle erupts over Patroclus's body. Automedon, Achilles' charioteer, is distressed. Alcimedon takes the reins of Achilles' immortal horses, and they attempt to defend the chariot from Æneas and Hector, who try to capture it. Automedon fights bravely, killing Aretus.

Minerva, sent by Jupiter, encourages Menelaus. Apollo, disguised as Phaenops, encourages Hector. Jupiter shakes his aegis, terrifying the Greeks. Idomeneus and Meriones are forced to retreat. Ajax, seeing the battle shrouded in darkness, prays to Jupiter to dispel the mist, even if it means their death. Jupiter grants his prayer, restoring light to the field.

Ajax then tells Menelaus to send Antilochus to Achilles with the news of Patroclus's death. Antilochus, weeping, runs to Achilles. Menelaus and Meriones, with the Ajaces defending them, bear Patroclus's body from the field towards the ships, facing continuous and furious Trojan resistance. The battle continues to rage around the retreating Greeks.

**Book XVIII: The Grief of Achilles, and New Armour Made Him by Vulcan.**
The battle continues fiercely. Antilochus, Nestor's son, brings the devastating news of Patroclus's death to Achilles. Achilles is overwhelmed with grief, casting dust over his head, tearing his hair, and rolling on the ground in agony. His captive women also lament.

Thetis, Achilles' mother, hears his cries from the depths of the sea and rises with her Nereid sisters to comfort him. Achilles tells his mother that he no longer wishes to live unless he can avenge Patroclus by killing Hector. He accepts his own fated death, which he knows will follow Hector's. Thetis, weeping, reminds him that he cannot fight without armor, as Hector has taken his. She promises to go to Vulcan to obtain new, divinely forged armor for him by dawn.

While Thetis departs for Olympus, the battle for Patroclus's body continues to rage. Hector is still attempting to drag the body away. Juno, seeing the Greeks in dire straits, secretly sends Iris to Achilles, ordering him to show himself at the trench to frighten the Trojans, even without armor. Achilles, inspired by Pallas, appears at the trench, shrouded in a golden cloud, with a flaming aura around his head. His loud shouts and terrifying appearance strike panic into the Trojans. Twelve Trojans are crushed in the ensuing chaos. The Greeks seize the opportunity to retrieve Patroclus's body and carry it to Achilles' tent.

As night falls, the sun sets, and the battle ends. The Trojans hold a council. Polydamas advises retreating into the city walls, fearing Achilles' return. Hector, however, rejects this counsel, insisting they remain on the plain to confront Achilles at dawn, believing he can defeat him. Pallas influences the Trojans to approve Hector's ill-fated advice.

Achilles continues to mourn Patroclus, vowing to avenge him and to sacrifice twelve Trojan youths on his pyre. He orders Patroclus's body to be washed and anointed.

Thetis arrives at Vulcan's palace on Olympus. Vulcan, grateful to Thetis for having saved him in the past, readily agrees to forge new armor for Achilles. He crafts a magnificent shield, depicting the cosmos, two cities (one at peace, one at war), agricultural scenes (ploughing, harvest, vineyard), a herd of oxen attacked by lions, a sheepfold, and a dancing ground, all encircled by the river Oceanus. He also forges a splendid cuirass, greaves, and a helmet. Thetis takes the blazing new armor and flies back to Achilles.

**Book XIX: The Reconciliation of Achilles and Agamemnon.**
At dawn, Thetis brings the magnificent, divinely forged armor to Achilles, finding him still mourning Patroclus. Achilles is awestruck by the armor but expresses concern about Patroclus's body decaying. Thetis reassures him, pouring nectar and ambrosia into Patroclus's nostrils to preserve the body from decay. She then instructs Achilles to assemble the Greeks and publicly renounce his wrath against Agamemnon.

Achilles obeys, calling the Greeks to an assembly. He declares his anger is over and he is ready to fight. Agamemnon, still wounded, rises and explains his past actions by blaming Ate (Delusion), recounting how even Jupiter was once deluded. He then formally offers all the gifts he had promised to Achilles. Achilles accepts the gifts but expresses his impatience to fight, his soul consumed by vengeance for Patroclus.

Ulysses intervenes, advising that the army must first eat and rest to regain strength for the arduous battle ahead. He also insists that Agamemnon publicly present the gifts and swear a solemn oath that he never touched Briseïs. Agamemnon agrees to all conditions. Ulysses, Nestor's sons, and other chiefs deliver the gifts to Achilles' tent. Agamemnon then takes the oath before the assembled Greeks, sacrificing a boar and swearing by Jupiter and the Furies that Briseïs was returned untouched. The sacrificed boar is thrown into the sea.

Achilles still refuses to eat, his grief for Patroclus overwhelming him. Briseïs, returned to his tent, sees Patroclus's body and laments him, recalling his kindness and his promises of marriage. Achilles continues to mourn, expressing his sorrow and his wish that Patroclus had lived to raise his son. Jupiter, seeing Achilles' refusal to eat, sends Minerva to infuse nectar and ambrosia into him, strengthening him for battle.

Achilles then dons his new, blazing armor, which shines like fire. He takes up his great spear, which only he can wield. Automedon and Alcimus prepare his immortal horses. Achilles addresses his horses, Xanthus and Balius, reproaching them for leaving Patroclus to die. Xanthus, miraculously given voice by Juno, tells Achilles that he will be safe this day, but his own death is near, fated by a god and a mortal. Achilles, undaunted by the prophecy, declares he knows his fate and rushes to battle, eager for vengeance.

**Book XX: The Battle of the Gods, and the Acts of Achilles.**
As Achilles prepares to re-enter battle, Jupiter convenes a council of the gods on Olympus. He grants permission for all deities to assist either the Greeks or the Trojans, fearing that Achilles, if left unchecked, might prematurely sack Troy against fate. The gods descend to the plain, their presence causing immense tumult and shaking the earth and Olympus, even disturbing Hades.

The gods take sides: Juno, Neptune, Minerva, Hermes, and Vulcan support the Greeks; Latona, Apollo, Mars, Diana, and Xanthus (the river god Scamander) support the Trojans. The divine forces prepare to clash.

Achilles, filled with boundless rage, seeks Hector. Apollo, disguised as Lycaon, encourages Æneas to confront Achilles. Æneas is initially hesitant, recalling past defeats by Achilles. They exchange boasts about their divine and heroic lineages. Æneas throws his spear, which strikes Achilles' divine shield but is repelled. Achilles throws his spear, which pierces Æneas's shield and grazes his back.

Neptune, seeing Æneas in peril and remembering Jupiter's will that Æneas is destined to survive and found a new line, intervenes. He shrouds Achilles' eyes in darkness, removes the spear from Æneas's shield, and carries Æneas away to the rear of the battle, warning him to avoid Achilles until Achilles' fated death.

Achilles, realizing a god intervened, resumes his rampage against the other Trojans. He kills Iphytion, Demoleon, Hippodamas, and Polydore (Priam's youngest son). Hector, enraged by Polydore's death, confronts Achilles, despite Apollo's warning to avoid single combat. Achilles throws his spear at Hector, but Pallas deflects it back to Achilles. Hector throws his spear, but Apollo shrouds him in a cloud, saving him from Achilles' wrath. Achilles, frustrated, vows to kill Hector later and continues his slaughter of other Trojans, including Dryops, Demuchus, Laoganus, Dardanus, Alastor, Mulius, Echeclus, Deucalion, Rhigmas, and his charioteer. The battlefield is deluged with blood and bodies as Achilles' chariot tramples the slain.

**Book XXI: The Battle in the River Scamander.**
The Trojans flee before Achilles, some towards the city, others plunging into the Scamander river. Juno creates a mist to aid those fleeing to the city. Achilles, abandoning his spear, plunges into the river with his sword, slaughtering Trojans and taking twelve captives alive for sacrifice to Patroclus.

He encounters Lycaon, a son of Priam whom he had previously captured and sold into slavery. Lycaon begs for his life, reminding Achilles of their past encounter and his royal lineage. Achilles, hardened by Patroclus's death, refuses mercy and brutally kills Lycaon, throwing his body into the river, insulting him and wishing all Trojans would perish similarly.

Achilles then confronts Asteropeus, a Paeonian leader and son of the river Axius. Asteropeus wounds Achilles' hand, but Achilles kills him, boasting of his superior divine lineage. He throws Asteropeus's body into the river.

The Scamander river, angered by the dead bodies choking its stream, rises in human form and commands Achilles to cease his slaughter. Achilles refuses, vowing to continue until Troy is sacked and Hector is dead. The river then unleashes a massive flood, sweeping away bodies and attacking Achilles. Achilles struggles against the torrent, clinging to an elm tree, which is uprooted. He is swept away.

Neptune and Pallas appear in human form, encouraging Achilles and promising divine aid against the river. They tell him to continue fighting until Hector is slain. Scamander calls upon his brother river, Simois, to help overwhelm Achilles. Juno, seeing Achilles in danger, calls upon Vulcan to unleash his fires against the rivers. Vulcan's flames consume the dead, dry the land, and cause the rivers to boil in agony. Scamander begs Juno to stop, promising to cease aiding Troy. Juno orders Vulcan to withdraw his flames.

With the river battle ended, the other gods engage in combat: Pallas strikes Mars with a stone, knocking him down. Venus rescues Mars, but Pallas strikes her too. Neptune challenges Apollo, but Apollo refuses to fight for mortals. Diana rebukes Apollo for his cowardice, but Juno attacks Diana, seizing her bow and quiver and striking her. Hermes refuses to fight Latona. The gods return to Olympus.

Apollo, still concerned for Troy, trembles for its walls as Achilles continues his slaughter. Priam orders the city gates opened for the fleeing Trojans. Apollo, disguised as Agenor, confronts Achilles. Achilles pursues the disguised Apollo, allowing the remaining Trojans to retreat safely into the city. The Trojans close their gates, safe from Achilles, while he is still deluded by Apollo.

**Book XXII: The Death of Hector.**
The Trojans, smitten with panic, rush back into the city walls. Only Hector remains outside the Scaean Gate, resolved to face Achilles alone. Apollo, revealing himself, tells Achilles he has been deluded, allowing the Trojans to escape. Achilles expresses anger at Apollo for hindering his pursuit.

From the city walls, Priam and Hecuba see Achilles approaching, blazing in his new armor. They desperately plead with Hector to come inside, fearing his imminent death. Hecuba bares her breast, reminding him of her maternal care. Hector, however, is torn by shame and duty. He debates whether to retreat, parley with Achilles, or fight. He rejects retreat due to the shame of Polydamas's earlier, rejected advice, and dismisses parley as futile. He resolves to fight.

As Achilles draws near, his divine armor gleaming like a star, Hector's resolve fails, and he flees in terror. Achilles pursues him three times around the walls of Troy. The gods observe the chase. Jupiter expresses pity for Hector, but Pallas (Minerva) persuades him to let fate take its course.

Pallas descends to aid Achilles. She disguises herself as Deiphobus, Hector's brother, and approaches Hector, encouraging him to make a stand and promising to fight alongside him. Hector, believing he has an ally, agrees. Hector proposes an oath to Achilles that the victor will return the loser's body for burial. Achilles furiously rejects any oaths, declaring his intent to kill Hector.

Achilles launches his spear, but Hector dodges it. Pallas, unseen by Hector, returns the spear to Achilles. Hector throws his spear, which strikes Achilles' divine shield but is repelled. Hector realizes Deiphobus is not there and that he has been deceived by a god. Accepting his fate, Hector draws his sword and charges Achilles. Achilles, knowing the weakness in Patroclus's armor (which Hector is wearing), plunges his spear into Hector's neck, killing him.

Achilles boasts over the dying Hector, refusing his plea for burial and vowing to leave his body for dogs and and vultures. Hector, with his last breath, prophesies Achilles' own death at the Scaean Gate by Paris and Apollo.

Achilles strips Hector's armor. Other Greeks gather around and stab Hector's body. Achilles then pierces Hector's ankles, binds them with thongs, and ties the body to his chariot. He drags Hector's body three times around Patroclus's tomb, then towards the ships, in full view of Priam and Hecuba on the walls. Priam and Hecuba are overcome with grief, wailing and tearing their hair. Andromache, unaware, hears the wailing, rushes to the walls, and faints at the sight of her dead husband being dragged. Recovering, she laments Hector's death and the grim future for their son, Astyanax, and Troy. She decides to burn Hector's unused robes as a final, symbolic offering.

**Book XXIII: Funeral Games in Honour of Patroclus.**
The Greeks mourn Patroclus. Achilles leads the Myrmidons in a chariot procession around Patroclus's body, lamenting. He reaffirms his vow to leave Hector's body for dogs and to sacrifice twelve Trojan captives on Patroclus's pyre. The Greeks then share a funeral feast. Achilles refuses to wash or cleanse himself until Patroclus is buried and instructs Agamemnon to prepare a large funeral pyre.

Achilles, exhausted, falls asleep on the shore. The ghost of Patroclus appears to him, asking for proper burial rites so his soul can find rest and prophesying Achilles' own impending death. He also requests that their bones be mixed in one golden urn. Achilles attempts to embrace the ghost but fails. He wakes, confirms the ghost's words, and renews his grief.

The next morning, the Greeks, led by Meriones, go to Mount Ida to cut timber for the pyre. The funeral procession takes place, with the Myrmidons in chariots, followed by foot soldiers, and then Patroclus's body on a bier. Achilles, supporting Patroclus's head, cuts off a lock of his own hair (vowed to the river Sperchius) and places it on the body.

The pyre is built, and Patroclus's body is laid upon it. Achilles sacrifices numerous sheep, oxen, four horses, and two dogs. Finally, he sacrifices twelve Trojan captives on the pyre. The pyre does not burn well, so Achilles prays to the Winds (Zephyr and Boreas). Iris, sent by Achilles, summons the Winds, who then cause the pyre to blaze fiercely all night.

At dawn, the flames subside. Achilles and the chiefs quench the embers with wine, carefully collect Patroclus's white bones, place them in a golden urn, and build a large earthen mound as a tomb.

Achilles then announces funeral games with various prizes.
1.  **Chariot Race:** Prizes include a woman and a tripod-vase (1st), a mare (2nd), a cauldron (3rd), gold talents (4th), and a double bowl (5th). Competitors are Eumelus, Diomed, Menelaus, Antilochus, and Meriones. Nestor advises his son, Antilochus, on strategy. Apollo strikes Diomed's whip, but Pallas restores it and causes Eumelus's chariot to break. Diomed wins 1st. Antilochus, using a cunning maneuver, takes 2nd from Menelaus. Menelaus takes 3rd, Meriones 4th, and Eumelus 5th. Achilles gives Eumelus a separate prize for his misfortune. Menelaus initially accuses Antilochus of foul play, but Antilochus apologizes and yields the prize, which Menelaus graciously allows him to keep. Achilles gives Nestor a special prize for his wisdom.
2.  **Boxing (Caestus) Match:** Epeüs and Euryalus compete. Epeüs, a large man, boasts of his strength and knocks Euryalus out with a single blow.
3.  **Wrestling Match:** Ajax Telamon and Ulysses compete. They grapple fiercely, but neither can throw the other. Achilles declares it a draw and awards them equal prizes.
4.  **Foot Race:** Oilean Ajax, Ulysses, and Antilochus compete. Ajax leads, then Ulysses. Pallas trips Ajax, causing him to fall in dung. Ulysses wins 1st, Antilochus 2nd, and Ajax 3rd. Ajax complains that a goddess helped Ulysses, and Antilochus makes a jest. Achilles awards Antilochus an extra gold talent.
5.  **Single Combat (Spear Fight):** Diomed and Ajax Telamon compete for Sarpedon's armor and a Thracian sword. They exchange spear thrusts. The Greeks stop the fight, declaring both worthy. Diomed is awarded the sword.
6.  **Discus Throw:** Polypoetes, Leonteus, Ajax, and Epeüs compete. Polypoetes throws a massive iron quoit the farthest and wins.
7.  **Archery Contest:** Merion and Teucer compete to shoot a dove tied to a mast. Teucer cuts the cord but misses the bird. Merion then shoots the bird as it flies away, winning the prize.
8.  **Javelin Throw:** Merion and Agamemnon compete. Achilles declares Agamemnon the best and awards him the charger, giving Merion the spear as a gift for Agamemnon's brother.

**Book XXIV: The Redemption of the Body of Hector.**
After the funeral games, the Greeks return to their ships, but Achilles remains consumed by grief for Patroclus. He continues to drag Hector's body around Patroclus's tomb daily. Apollo, pitying Hector, protects his body from mutilation and decay.

The gods are moved by compassion for Hector and his family. Apollo argues for the return of Hector's body, criticizing Achilles' excessive cruelty. Juno, still implacable towards Troy, opposes this. Jupiter, however, decrees that Hector's body must be returned. He sends Thetis to Achilles to command him to accept ransom. Thetis finds Achilles mourning and delivers Jupiter's message. Achilles, though still grieving, agrees to obey the will of the gods.

Jupiter then sends Iris to Priam, instructing the aged king to go alone to Achilles' tent with rich gifts to ransom Hector's body. He is to take only an aged herald and mules, and Hermes will guide and protect him. Despite Hecuba's desperate pleas and warnings against the danger, Priam, encouraged by Jupiter's command, resolves to go. He gathers a vast array of gifts from his treasury. He laments his lost sons and harshly rebukes his surviving sons before departing. Hecuba offers a libation to Jupiter and asks for an omen, which Jupiter provides by sending an eagle.

Priam departs with the herald Idæus, driving the car with the gifts and mules. Jupiter sends Hermes, disguised as a young Myrmidon, to guide and protect them. Hermes meets Priam and Idæus at a spring, reassures Priam, and reveals that Hector's body is still intact and preserved by the gods. Hermes puts the Greek guards to sleep, opens the gates, and leads Priam and the gifts into Achilles' tent. He then reveals his divine identity and vanishes.

Priam enters, kneels before Achilles, embraces his knees, and kisses his hands (the hands that killed his son). He appeals to Achilles' memory of his own aged father, Peleus, and begs for Hector's body, offering the ransom. Achilles is deeply moved by Priam's plea, remembering his own father and Patroclus. Both men weep in shared grief.

Achilles raises Priam and speaks of the common lot of human suffering, urging Priam to bear his grief. Priam reiterates his plea for Hector's body. Achilles, angered by Priam's persistence but mindful of Jupiter's command, agrees to return Hector's body. He orders his handmaids to wash, anoint, and wrap Hector's body in fine garments, out of Priam's sight, to prevent further outbursts of rage. As the body is placed on the car, Achilles speaks to Patroclus's shade, asking forgiveness for returning Hector, but noting it is Jupiter's will.

Achilles invites Priam to a meal, telling him the story of Niobe to encourage him to eat. They eat together, admiring each other. Priam asks for a twelve-day truce for Hector's funeral rites, which Achilles grants. Priam and Idæus sleep in the porch. Hermes awakens Priam before dawn, warning him of the danger of being discovered by the Greeks, and guides them safely out of the camp.

Priam and Idæus return to Troy at dawn. Cassandra is the first to see them from the city walls and alerts the city. The Trojans rush out to meet the wain. Andromache, Hecuba, and Helen lead the lamentations over Hector's body. Andromache mourns Hector and fears for their son Astyanax's future. Hecuba mourns Hector, noting his body's preservation by the gods. Helen mourns Hector, calling him her only kind friend in Troy.

The Trojans then gather wood for nine days. On the tenth day, Hector's body is burned on a pyre. His bones are collected in a golden urn, wrapped in purple, and buried in a tomb. Strong guards watch the tomb. Finally, the Trojans hold a funeral feast. The mighty Hector's shade rests peacefully.

**Comparison and Analysis:**

**Coverage of Events, Characters, and Plot Points:**

   - The generated summary is a detailed, book-by-book retelling of the events of the Iliad, covering all 24 books in sequence.
